dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A desolate-seeming, visually magnificent landscape. We we looking at clouds, and they form glorious patterns in the lowered sky. Like a painting by Lorraine, or Corot, or Turner. The horizon is dark, almost charcoal black. A thin layer of fog drifts slowly across that abstract surface. As the FOG MOVES, it reveals: a MAN. He has been running towards us. A silhouette. Like the re of the opening image, his appearance to us should conjure PRIMAL, the MYTHIC, the ELEMENTAL. It is as though he wer born out of this fog, this cosmic force. He emerges from the fog. It is PERCY HARRISON FAWCETT. Thirties and handsome. Not exactly a youngster, but not creaky and old, either. Strikes us as cheerful. A gentle voice, an even manner. Despite his cheer and charm, howev there is something steely about him, resolved, committed. His eyes reveal a far more complex person than the exteri might first allow; behind their twinkle there lurks a capacity for furious wrath and implacable resolution, the more dangerous because they are held in leash... Over the wind now, we begin to HEAR CHURCH BELLS RINGING. Fawcett himself gets closer and closer to us... We HEAR a WOMAN'S VOICE, distant: WOMAN’S VOICE Percy! Percy! +e HF

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ee

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: +e %  Lost City of Z Blue Revision Set 8/19/15 2. The CAMERA PULLS BACK to reveal a SILHOUETTE in the foreground, through a doorway. A WOMAN’S FORM.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Outside a rural church. A woman steps toward the outer fence, holding a small baby. She is waiting for Percy, it seems. The WOMAN is NINA FAWCETT. The baby is JACK FAWCET their newborn son. Nina Fawcett, thirties, is bubbly and flighty, but also highly cultured. Brash at times, a woman of independent curiosity. There are a few other people, of varying ages and shapes sizes, right behind her. All look happy, very happy. Amon them: JAMES BERNARD, 4th EARL OF BANDON ("LORD BERNARD”), seventies, piercing eyes, intense. Percy ARRIVES AT LAST. He meets her and the child. He embraces her, and the couple look ecstatic, glowing.

dialogues.speaker: NINA FAWCETT
dialogues.text: We’d no doubt you’d be here-- (to the baby) DID we, Jack.

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: The men made a complete hash of drill and I had to set them to rights. (looks at the other people) Good afternoon all... We're very grateful for your attendance today. (back to Nina) Shall we, darling?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is a rural Irish church, lovely, with history. We are toward the end of a CHRISTENING CEREMONY. SUPERIMPOSE: “CORK, IRELAND, 1903” A MINISTER is here, putting the christening robe on the b He anoints him with oil, and as he does he speaks. While speaks, we have a CLOSE SHOT on the INFANT’S HAND. Percy' hand caresses it. Then a CLOSE SHOT on PERCY--a smile, th a kind of regression into thought. HE GETS EMOTIONAL... + eH  Lost City of Z Blue Revision Set 8/19/15 2A.

dialogues.speaker: MINISTER
dialogues.text: May God, who has received you by baptism into his Church, pour upon you the riches of his grace...  Lost City of Z Blue Revision Set 8/19/15 3.

dialogues.speaker: WHILE HE IS FINISHING HIS SPEECH
dialogues.text: MANDALA NECKLACE, which she HANGS AROUND the CHILD'S HEAD The others nearby who see this are flummoxed for a moment Except for Percy, who touches the mandala with a surprisi reverence... Those IN ATTENDANCE finish things with an “AMEN”. The Minister then turns to Percy and Nina and the others:

dialogues.speaker: MINISTER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: As this is a private ceremony, I shall take the liberty to welcome Jack’s parents back from Ceylon, where they have been stationed for three years. I know Major Percy Fawcett and his lovely wife, Nina to be fine people, who, though they have often pursued their own path, remain committed to making their family a true support of our Christian community. A “HERE HERE” from those in attendance. All converge on Percy and Nina and baby Jack. James Bernard, 4th Earl of Bandon ("LORD BERNARD”) approaches Nina and Percy:

dialogues.speaker: LORD BERNARD
dialogues.text: What a beautiful ceremony. Such a precious child--congratulations to you both. And no doubt, great comfort after such a difficult birth.

dialogues.speaker: NINA FAWCETT
dialogues.text: Thank you, Lord Bernard. It WAS a very near thing, and there was much concern. But all is well now.

dialogues.speaker: LORD BERNARD
dialogues.text: Of course, of course! (turns to Percy) A word to the wise--been very difficult for many of the men at the Fort to find a nanny of good character.

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: We intend to raise the boy ourselves, Lord Bernard--we don’t wish for our children to be strangers. (to Nina) Our children will become our dearest companions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lost City of Z White 7/31/15 4.

dialogues.speaker: LORD BERNARD
dialogues.text: (as though they were insane) Ah... I see...very well, then... I...wish you the very best... Fawcett nods to Bernard, then, beaming, turns back to his wife. With great expectation and tenderness, to his wife:

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: Our lives begin anew today... We begin to HEAR: a GALLOPING HORSE: THUMPITY THUMPITY THUMPITY... LOUDER AND LOUDER...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Fort: large and foreboding. SILHOUETTED, the sun behind: MOUNTED SOLDIERS ON HORSES, galloping in circles. PERCY FAWCETT is dressed impeccably atop his horse; he wears a crisp uniform with gold button and a spiked helmet strapped under his chin. NEAR A WALL AT THE CHURCH: a GROUP OF OLDER MEN, standing and WOMEN, seated, with their children. With umbrellas ab their heads, fans in hand. NINA is here, holding JACK, NO AGE 3. IRISH BAGPIPES and DRUMS are playing; children are dancing. LORD BERNARD is here, standing near NINA. ANGLE ON: a HUNT LEADER, late forties. He is surrounded b the mounted soldiers, ready for a big moment. LOUDLY:

dialogues.speaker: HUNT LEADER
dialogues.text: Gentlemen! I expect you to behave with distinction on this hunt! The deer will be delivered to the Archduke Ferdinand at the gala! Remember: honor, duty, and good sportsmanship are the cornerstones of our proud civilization! Good luck and godspeed! Fawcett sees them in the distance. They wave to him. In return, he explodes in warmth, waves. OTHER SOLDIERS circ FAWCETT, ribbing him in their soldierly way:

dialogues.speaker: OTHER SOLDIER
dialogues.text: Could they not fit your rocking chair on the horse, granddad?!? + eH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: +e * HF

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lost City of Z White 7/31/15 5.

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: You’1l all be my gunbearers by evening--have no doubt of that!

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: Who sits many feet away.

dialogues.speaker: NINA FAWCETT
dialogues.text: (in the boy's ear) Wave, to your father... The child waves, and PERCY, THRILLED, WAVES BACK. ANOTHER SOLIDER BLOWS a HORN. Fawcett and the REST OF THE MEN ON HORSEBACK break out wi great determination. Fawcett YELLS at, KICKS, his horse..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A WILD DEER, a buck with big antlers, speeds through the grass. Hounds BARK, running through the terrain... The PACK OF HORSES, FAWCETT AMONG THEM, chases behind. We HEAR the distant WHOOPS, the CHEERS, the HORNS, the EXULTATION of the MOUNTED TROOPS charging in pursuit of t deer... PERCY FAWCETT is on his horse, HOOTING, as are the others The Other Soldiers RIDE NEXT TO HIM--COMPETITIVE and SOUR FACED that he rides off in a different direction:

dialogues.speaker: OTHER SOLDIER
dialogues.text: Fawcett! There’s no path there! FAWCETT! You’re mad! FAWCETT RIDES OFF into another direction--where there is path. THE HOUNDS run as though their lives depend on it, BARKING rabidly in pursuit... THE DEER is running because its life DOES depend on it... The horses are kicked until bloody... HORSE after HORSE tumbles from rough terrain, and many of MEN--UNLIKE FAWCETT--are not able to continue...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FAWCETT kicks/whips his horse with astonishing drive, and does an end-run around many of his competitors, cutting t off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lost City of Z Blue Revision Set 8/19/15 6. The deer, meanwhile, enters a nearby area of dense, tall grass. It runs in a circle, entangled by the weeds. FAWCE approaches the animal. Fawcett takes out his RIFLE... HE FIRES. The deer stumble to the ground. JUST THEN, YOUNG SOLDIERS ARRIVE AT THE SCENE, hounds too. Fawcett watches the animal die. One of the soldiers examins the deer and calls out, “DEAD A CHEER. The men pass a FLASK to Fawcett, who takes a swi

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: To death--the best sauce to life! Some of the men let out another LOUD CHEER as others are considerably more disappointed...

dialogues.speaker: NEAR THE CHURCH
dialogues.text: Fawcett goes to his BABY SON and beaming Nina. He kisses Nina, then HOLDS THE CHILD HIGH, kisses him. A HUGE GRIN from the happy father amidst cheers. Music up: “Avrem Lieta,” from Giuseppe Verdi’s LA TRAVIAT forceful and upbeat waltz:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fawcett approaches his barracks door. We PASS a GROUP of SINGING TROOPS.

dialogues.speaker: ARMY SOLDIERS
dialogues.text: And I never get a knock when the boys call Cock, cockity ock ock, cock Robin! In my old red vest, I mean to cut a shine, walking down the street they call me ‘Danger on the Line!’ Then:

dialogues.speaker: SERIES OF SHOTS
dialogues.text: 1. MEDIUM SHOT - The Fawcett RESIDENCE. FILLED WITH CLUTT With THREE FOX TERRIERS MOVING ABOUT. 2. CLOSE SHOT - a STATUE OF THE BUDDHA. eH HH FH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lost City of Z Blue Revision Set 8/19/15 6A. 3. CLOSE SHOT - a STACK of LEAFLETS on a DESK: “VOTES FOR

dialogues.speaker: WOMEN
dialogues.text: 4. MEDIUM SHOT - a JOYOUS little JACK, with his stuffed animal, plays with the dogs. 5. CLOSE SHOT - All the formal wear for Percy Fawcett LAI A BED. A HAND REACHES down, PICKS UP a PIECE OF CLOTHING. TILT UP to REVEAL: PERCY PUTTING IT ON. He looks STIFF, b bemused. 6. CLOSE SHOT - A WOMAN, a MAID, is STRUGGLING with SOMETHING. WIDEN to REVEAL: SHE is HELPING NINA get into CORSET. Nina spots Percy, all finished dressing. He STAND in the DOORWAY, silhouetted, watching. (Young ARMY SOLDIERS are outside, chanting: )  Lost City of Z Blue Revision Set 8/19/15 7.

dialogues.speaker: NINA FAWCETT
dialogues.text: Oh, this damned thing! (to Percy) You must be so pleased with yourselves, you men! Making us wear these awful things! She then adjusts her HAIR:

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: If you keep refusing to wear your hair as the others do, at least you'll not appear tonight in trousers. The MAID LEAVES. His smiles deserts him; he looks at his

dialogues.speaker: POCKET WATCH
dialogues.text: PERCY FAWCETT (CONT’D) We're going to be late. Nina fixes herself for another beat, then:

dialogues.speaker: NINA FAWCETT
dialogues.text: Done. (beat; showing herself) Well?

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: Rather lovely.

dialogues.speaker: NINA FAWCETT
dialogues.text: “Rather lovely”. Thank you! You look “rather” well yourself! Percy nods. Then says nothing. She eyes him for a moment, then, turning back to the mirror: NINA FAWCETT (CONT’D) All right, out with it. What’s amiss?

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: I'll be the only man there tonight of my rank whose uniform is unadorned.

dialogues.speaker: NINA FAWCETT
dialogues.text: My God, that again? + eH  Lost City of Z White 7/31/15 8.

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: The great Secretary Bryce will be in attendance. (mocking voice; as a joke) "Oh Major Fawcett, have you no medals? Oh no, Mr. Bryce--I've been quite busy training ancient militia men to point their rifles at tree stumps. So--no medals for me.” He sits down near her. She sits on his lap, KISSES him. Then she leans back.

dialogues.speaker: NINA FAWCETT
dialogues.text: Who's this Mr. Bryce when he’s at home?

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: The last man here upon whom we might possibly rely for advancement.

dialogues.speaker: NINA FAWCETT
dialogues.text: I see. A beat. Then:

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: (more serious now) I’m getting older, Cheeky. And very impatient of lost years. I know the tokens are ridiculous. I do. But I think of our boy--we cannot close any doors to him.

dialogues.speaker: NINA FAWCETT
dialogues.text: (smiles gently) Then let us be off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The MUSIC CONTINUES. The camera BEGINS on a CLOSE SHOT of WALTZING COUPLE, then PULLS BACK TO REVEAL: A GALA for FRANZ FERDINAND, Archduke of Austria-Este and presumptive to the Austro-Hungarian throne. An enormous ballroom in a mansion, with tens of couples dancing in seeming unison, twirling around and around, almost like dolls. CLOSE SHOT: THE DEER. Laid out... THE ARCHDUKE STANDS in receiving line with OFFICERS. SHAKES HANDS, SMILING.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: + eH  Lost City of Z White 7/31/15 9. LORD BERNARD and BRIGADIER GENERAL SIDNEY VARNON THORNTON forties, are here with him. ACROSS THE ROOM: PERCY AND NINA FAWCETT ENTER, their imag reflected multiple times on a wall of mirrors. Fawcett no greetings to his fellow officers; Nina SPEAKS GREETINGS i GERMAN to an officer from Austria as all women check out handsome Percy...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fawcett and Nina move through the crowd. Many recognize them; random PARTYGOERS pass by, say hello.

dialogues.speaker: LORD BERNARD
dialogues.text: Good evening, Madame Nina... You're looking wonderful... Major... Welcome. So happy to have you here. The two acknowledge the hellos.

dialogues.speaker: MOMENTS LATER
dialogues.text: Percy and Nina are in the middle of the dance floor. They pose for a moment, about to start a waltz. And then they start dancing to the rhythm of the Verdi. Fawcett and Nina are fine dancers, blessed with grace but also training.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: here at the head of a receiving line. TROOPS ready the de to present to the Archduke.

dialogues.speaker: SECRETARY BRYCE
dialogues.text: Your majesty--I present to you this fine animal, a gift from our government to yours, and a recognition of our shared history and mutal interests. The ARCHDUKE BOWS IN GRATITUDE, ACCEPTS THE DEER. Bryce ushers the Archduke toward an antechamber. As he does, Br turns to Lord Bernard. SECRETARY BRYCE (CONT’D) Lord Bernard, we do appreciate the use of your magnificent home.

dialogues.speaker: LORD BERNARD
dialogues.text: Oh, it is my pleasure. We’ve seen far too little of this type of cheer these past few seasons.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: +e * HF

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: + eH  Lost City of Z White 7/31/15 10.

dialogues.speaker: SECRETARY BRYCE
dialogues.text: Yes, a fine showing by the men... By the way, who got the kill?

dialogues.speaker: LORD BERNARD
dialogues.text: (pointing him out) That would be Major Fawcett, Mr. Secretary.

dialogues.speaker: SECRETARY BRYCE
dialogues.text: Well then, invite him in for a drink! Bernard gives a SLIGHT WAVE OF HIS HAND; then:

dialogues.speaker: LORD BERNARD
dialogues.text: (moves closer) A bit odd. And, may I say, not entirely... fortunate in his choice of ancestors.

dialogues.speaker: SECRETARY BRYCE
dialogues.text: (comprehending somehow) I see. Right, then...

dialogues.speaker: FAWCETT AND NINA DANCE
dialogues.text: Around and around. Fawcett SEES the OFFICERS STARING AT H and he can TELL they are talking about him--and not ina flattering way, either. A LAUGH, a SNICKER...

dialogues.speaker: HE IS DISRESPECTED, AND HE KNOWS IT.
dialogues.text: They are toasting each other. Nina sees the line too as t dance and turn:

dialogues.speaker: NINA FAWCETT
dialogues.text: They're toasting the kill without you. Fawcett looks, then turns back:

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: Well, I am dancing with you. So I’ve got the better of the bargain. An OLDER OFFICER, THOMAS FRANCIS BUSBY, cuts in:

dialogues.speaker: THOMAS FRANCIS BUSBY
dialogues.text: May I, Major?

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: I'm afraid I’ve spoken too soon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: +e HH OH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lost City of Z White 7/31/15 11. As is the custom, Fawcett bows gracefully, nods his assen gives his wife to Busby, who is short and pudgy. Nina and Percy lock eyes; they are not given chance to sp Off Busby and Nina go, dancing. Percy takes out a CIGAR. He LOOKS at Secretary Bryce and Lord Bernard and Sidney Thornton and the rest of the offi as they then enter a smaller antechamber. And the DOOR is CLOSED ON HIM. And US. We TILT DOWN. PERCY BREAKS THE CIGAR in TWO.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SUPERIMPOSE THE LEGEND: “APRIL, 1906”. Troops load ARTILLERY SHELLS onto CARTS which are dragged horses. The shells are heavy; and the troops stand knee-d in the muddy water. Fawcett is supervising an OFFICER:

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: Each can contain no more than twelve shells, Corporal...

dialogues.speaker: OFFICER
dialogues.text: (to the grunts) Come on! Put your backs into it! The OFFICER CANES A GRUNT. Fawcett cannot hide his distas Turning his back to the troops, in the Officer's face, he grabs the cane:

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: We lead the men--we don’t beat them into submission! The Officer registers this, his head sinking in shame. A SOLDIER drops a shell; they holler in caution at one another. Then an OFFICER BARKS from behind:

dialogues.speaker: BARKING VOICE
dialogues.text: Fawcett! Fawcett looks up: COMMANDING OFFICER SIDNEY VARNON THORNT and THOMAS FRANCIS BUSBY. They approach him. Fawcett salutes.

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: Sir!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 10 Lost City of Z White 7/31/15 12.

dialogues.speaker: SIDNEY VARNON THORNTON
dialogues.text: You're off to London tomorrow. To the Royal Geographical Society.

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: Sir? The Royal Geographical--?

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: No, sir!

dialogues.speaker: SIDNEY VARNON THORNTON
dialogues.text: Best bring your long johns. You might well be off to the North Pole. THORNTON turns and leaves Fawcett standing there. ANGLE O FAWCETT as we GO TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: London. Busy, cluttered, noisy, dirty. We PAN TO REVEAL a TOWNHOUSE in CENTRAL LONDON, with a sign in front: “ROYAL GEOGRAPHICAL SOCIETY”. Fawcett approaches, enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A big wooden space. Regal. Standing behind his desk: SIR GEORGE GOLDIE. Goldie, sixties, with intense blue eyes an keen intelligence. Seated nearby: SIR JOHN SCOTT KELTIE, also sixties. Fawcett enters. Goldie does not look up fro his notes. Keltie does, but says nothing. He merely clear his throat, with no reaction for Goldie. After an awkward beat, Percy KNOCKS:

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: Sir? Major Fawcett--the War Office sent me?

dialogues.speaker: SIR GEORGE GOLDIE
dialogues.text: Oh yes yes--come in! I am Sir George Goldie. President of the RGS. This is Sir John Scott Keltie, our Secretary.

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: (as they shake) How do you do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: + eH  Lost City of Z Yellow Revision Set 8/6/15 13.

dialogues.speaker: SIR JOHN SCOTT KELTIE
dialogues.text: Good morning, Major.

dialogues.speaker: SIR GEORGE GOLDIE
dialogues.text: Our paths did not cross during your work here some years back.

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: No they did not, sir. I was likely consumed with my studies at the time.

dialogues.speaker: SIR GEORGE GOLDIE
dialogues.text: Of course. Please, sit down... (F. does; a beat, then) You've gone on several missions in the past, I see?

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: Yes. I’ve served in Ceylon, and in Hong Kong as well. I’ve...not stayed in one place for very long. Goldie looks down at a stack of papers. Keltie speaks up:

dialogues.speaker: SIR JOHN SCOTT KELTIE
dialogues.text: You also served in intelligence, in Morocco? Is that correct? NO ANSWER from FAWCETT. Goldie looks to Keltie, vaguely i disgust:

dialogues.speaker: SIR GEORGE GOLDIE
dialogues.text: Are you referring to the yellow document? The YELLOW document?

dialogues.speaker: SIR JOHN SCOTT KELTIE
dialogues.text: I beg your pardon, sir. Let’s pass on.

dialogues.speaker: SIR GEORGE GOLDIE
dialogues.text: (beat; back to Percy) Your time in Ceylon--there are rumors you went Buddhist. Such an act would of course be seditious.

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: Sir, my record speaks for itself. No one can question my commitment to King and country.

dialogues.speaker: SIR JOHN SCOTT KELTIE
dialogues.text: ARE you a Buddhist, Major?  Lost City of Z Blue Revision Set 8/19/15 14.

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: My experience in the Orient taught me that no religion is higher than truth. I make no apologies. A pregnant pause. Then Goldie leans forward:

dialogues.speaker: SIR GEORGE GOLDIE
dialogues.text: Major, what do you know about Bolivia?

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: In South America, sir?

dialogues.speaker: SIR GEORGE GOLDIE
dialogues.text: That’s right.

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: Only what I’ve read. Goldie chuckles. An atlas is put in front of Fawcett.

dialogues.speaker: SIR GEORGE GOLDIE
dialogues.text: Then you can’t know very much. This’s about as good a map of Bolivia as we have. The map literally says “UNEXPLORED”. Referring to the map As Goldie SIR GEORGE GOLDIE (CONT’D) Most of it’s blank, as you can see. Nothing’s really known of it at all. The rivers are all a guess. These are rubber centers here--very profitable. Some are even apparently quite lavish. forwards another book: SIR GEORGE GOLDIE (CONT’D) There is now considerable argument between Bolivia and Brazil, over what constitutes their borders. So fantastically high is the price of rubber that war could arise. Do you follow?

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: I do, sir. But with respect--I’m not sure what it has to do with me. Sir.

dialogues.speaker: SIR GEORGE GOLDIE
dialogues.text: I’m getting to that.  Lost City of Z White 7/31/15 15. Goldie moves closer to Fawcett, to the edge of the desk: SIR GEORGE GOLDIE (CONT’D) Neither country will accept mapping done by the other, so they’ve requested us to act--as referee. Keltie gets up, stands next to Goldie:

dialogues.speaker: SIR JOHN SCOTT KELTIE
dialogues.text: As you completed your courses in mapping here with distinction, you came under our consideration.

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: Sirs--to be honest, my survey work was long ago. And I was...I was really hoping for a posting where I might be able to see a fair bit of action.

dialogues.speaker: SIR GEORGE GOLDIE
dialogues.text: Oh, I do understand your concern-- we're aware you’ve never faced a shot fired in anger. But Major, this is far more than just survey work. It’s exploration, in the jungle. The environment is brutally difficult. There’s terrible disease and murderous savages. The journey may well mean your life. But should you succeed, such an undertaking could earn you soldierly decoration--AND even reclaim your family name.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goldie leans back. Then: SIR GEORGE GOLDIE (CONT’D) You know, we knew your father.

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: Did you. I did not.

dialogues.speaker: SIR JOHN SCOTT KELTIE
dialogues.text: Terrible thing, a man’s love of drink... And gaming...

dialogues.speaker: SIR GEORGE GOLDIE
dialogues.text: But: as I say, success in this venture could change your lot. Considerably. Fawcett looks back down at the map. “UNEXPLORED”. +e * HF

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: + eH  11 Lost City of Z White 7/31/15 16.

dialogues.speaker: SIR JOHN SCOTT KELTIE
dialogues.text: Well, Major? What’s it going to be? ANGLE ON FAWCETT as he looks up. He SMILES.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANGLE ON JACK, playing in the sand. WIDEN: Fawcett and Ni near him. As Fawcett stares at the kid:

dialogues.speaker: NINA FAWCETT
dialogues.text: He’1ll not know you when you return. Fawcett nods. A beat. Then:

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: You must protect him from the sort of schooling to which I was subjected.

dialogues.speaker: NINA FAWCETT
dialogues.text: (of COURSE!) Our minds are as one on this, have no fear of that.

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: (to himself; aloud) I‘1l not have him caned for wearing the wrong frock coat...

dialogues.speaker: NINA FAWCETT
dialogues.text: Puggy-— (beat) I must tell you--I believe I’m going to have another child. He turns to look at her directly. A half-smile:

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: Another child...?

dialogues.speaker: NINA FAWCETT
dialogues.text: But this cannot distract you, or lead you to doubt my capacities. I’m an independent woman. And our children could have no better protector than their own mother.

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: I do not doubt you. (moves closer to her; touches her abdomen) (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: eH FH HH FF HH FH HK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: + eH  12 13 Lost City of Z White 7/31/15

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The thought of you all will be my greatest inspiration. I swear to you, I shall succeed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still dark. Fawcett is packed and ready to go. A SHOT OF HIS SUITCASES. Fawcett stands just outside Jack’s bedroom Turns around to see his wife. Nina’s back is to us; she i about to put Fawcett’s coat over his suitcase, but instea chooses to caress the coat with enormous tenderness. As

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: though the coat were a living thing, a beautiful child...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She SLIPS a BOOKLET into his COAT. He comes up behind her touches her shoulders. She whispers, afraid to wake up Ja

dialogues.speaker: NINA FAWCETT
dialogues.text: I've given you a book of poems, for * your journey. * He nods in appreciation. Matter-of-factly, without self- pity: *

dialogues.speaker: NINA FAWCETT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: One more kiss, please. We may never meet again. But A VOICE interrupts:

dialogues.speaker: JACK FAWCETT, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: Papa? INT. JACK’'S BEDROOM 13 Fawcett enters the bedroom, stands over his son. Also * whispered:

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: It’s still very early, my boy. You should go back to sleep.

dialogues.speaker: JACK FAWCETT
dialogues.text: Where are you going?

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: Far away. You're to look after your mother.

dialogues.speaker: JACK FAWCETT
dialogues.text: I want to come. Fawcett sits at the edge of the bed:  Lost City of Z White 7/31/15 18.

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: Darling, I'm afraid it’s no place for children.

dialogues.speaker: JACK FAWCETT
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: Because there’s great danger.

dialogues.speaker: JACK FAWCETT
dialogues.text: Then why are you going?

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: We must all do our duty for King and country, first and foremost.

dialogues.speaker: JACK FAWCETT
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: Well...this is how we keep the world civilized.

dialogues.speaker: JACK FAWCETT
dialogues.text: What is civilized? Fawcett laughs at all the questions. Then:

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: Goodbye, darling.

dialogues.speaker: JACK FAWCETT
dialogues.text: I want to come with you--

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: Perhaps someday you will. I love you most deeply. Nina enters from behind them.

dialogues.speaker: NINA FAWCETT
dialogues.text: Jack, give your father his present. Jack grins, reaches under his pillow, gives his father a small box. Inside: a gold ring. It’s all Fawcett can do t not burst into tears. He begins to get choked up:

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: It’s--it’s lovely. An inscription is on it: NEC ASPERA TERRENT.  14 15 Lost City of Z White 7/31/15 19.

dialogues.speaker: JACK FAWCETT
dialogues.text: What do the words say, Papa?

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: It means, “difficulties be damned”. (beat) Thank you so much for my beautiful gift. When I see you next, you'll be ready to sit a horse.

dialogues.speaker: NINA FAWCETT
dialogues.text: Now give your father a proper kiss so that he may be on his way... They boy sits up; Fawcett hugs, kisses him tightly as Nin looks on. TEARS BEGIN TO STREAM DOWN FAWCETT’S CHEEKS, bu he SMILES TO THE CHILD THROUGH THE TEARS. A SHIP HORN:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A ship steams on the ocean. The S.S. PANAMA.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fawcett sits in the cramped, dirty hold, which is filled toughs and scoundrels. Meanwhile, he looks clean-cut in a starched white collar, focused intently on a SPANISH LANG BOOK. Passengers drink whiskey, spit tobacco, play dice. And sing in a drunken stupor. A PICKPOCKET is reaching around, attempting to filch something out of Fawcett’s hanging coat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fawcett SEES this in the REFLECTION of a MIRROR that a ma using for shaving, across from his bunk. He wraps his han around a handkerchief, and with great speed, he pulls it around the neck of the Pickpocket and yanks him forward. Pulls out his REVOLVER:

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: I should think twice if I were you. The PICKPOCKET simply withdraws his hand. A BIG FIGHT bre out between two DRUNKS in the game. Fawcett turns to look ANOTHER MAN, clutching a rifle, standing with his arm aro a woman who might well be a prostitute, catches Fawcett’s eye. The Man takes a SWIG from a FLASK. Fawcett goes back to his reading...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: +e * HF  16 17 Lost City of Z White 7/31/15 20.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fawcett, smoking inside the ship, walking from the dining room. IN THE DISTANCE, DOWN THE DECK HALL: he SPOTS the MAN wit the rifle again, now slung on his back. And the man is staring back at him. Odd. Suspicious. Fawcett walks around, to the other side of the ship. And MAN APPEARS AGAIN. AGAIN, staring at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fawcett walks around the deck and opens a door. He ducks into a pantry. Dark. Pulls out his weapon. Through the grated metal window in the door, we see a SILHOUETTE approach. A beat, as the silhouette looks inside. The DOORKNOB moves. Fawcett MOVES behind the door. The door opens and the man comes in. Instantly, Fawcett WRAPS his FOREARM AROUND THE MAN'S NECK. The MAN PUSHES ON FAWCETT’S FACE. They TUSSLE, awkwardly, even humorously, each trying to out-tough the other, each proving himself sillier than the other. When they separate, the Man PULLS a KNIFE. Fawcett turns on the light, a solitary bulb that is turne or off by a string. The light SWINGS, back and forth.

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: Who are you? He is CORPORAL HENRY COSTIN, twenties, with a bold Kiplingesque mustache and heavily-hooded eyes. Exceptiona fit, having been a gymnastics instructor in the Army.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY COSTIN
dialogues.text: I’m Corporal Henry Costin, sir! I saw your advert in the Times--I'1l be your aide-de-camp on the mission!

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: (incredulous; upset) We've been at sea a week--why in God’s name haven’t you revealed yourself until now?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: + eH + eH  Lost City of Z White 7/31/15 21.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY COSTIN
dialogues.text: Had to make certain you were up to the task, sir! I’m not looking to get killed because you’re too long in the tooth!

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: You're speaking rather loudly, Mr. Costin.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY COSTIN
dialogues.text: (softer) Sorry, sir. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: And what if I were?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY COSTIN
dialogues.text: Were what, sir?

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: Too long in the tooth.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY COSTIN
dialogues.text: Ah--well, then I would assume command. Sir. (beat) I wasn’t planning to hurt you.

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: I assumed as much--you’re carrying that ridiculous rifle. Fawcett backs up, puts away his knife. Said as a command: PERCY FAWCETT (CONT’D) Where’s your paperwork. Costin reaches into his coat, pulls out a stack of paper, along with a small whiskey flask. And a small, tarnished medal with a ribbon. Fawcett looks at all of it.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY COSTIN
dialogues.text: It’s a medal. For bravery, against the Boer. (beat) I'm skilled, with both pistol and rifle, as you can see.

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: (as he looks at the papers) I myself have never been in war.  Lost City of Z White 7/31/15 22.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY COSTIN
dialogues.text: It was a fine time, sir. Gave us a real taste of glory.

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: You've a family, Mr. Costin?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY COSTIN
dialogues.text: None at all.

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: Good. Nothing to shed.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY COSTIN
dialogues.text: But you do, I take it then?

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: Yes. A wife and a boy, with another child on the way.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY COSTIN
dialogues.text: (vaguely challenging) And you'll have no difficulty shedding them?

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: Mr. Costin, my reputation as a man rests entirely on our success. You shall find me capable of every sacrifice.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY COSTIN
dialogues.text: Well I must say, I for one am fair itching for action.

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: I’m certain you won't be disappointed. You’1ll need every last bit of fortitude you've got. Therefore, I must insist-- Fawcett takes Costin’s whiskey flask. PERCY FAWCETT (CONT’D) You’1l need no more Dutch courage. g As Fawcett pours it into a nearby sink in the pantry, sot PERCY FAWCETT (CONT’D) [It’s] destroyed many a fine man. The alcohol runs along the sink bottom. We MATCH CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: + eH +e * HF + eH  18 19 Lost City of Z Green Revision Set 09/30/2015 23.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A TRAIN rockets through the area.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A crummy and cramped and loud interior. Filled with Boliv and indigenous peoples. Fawcett talks inaudibly with a Bolivian, then walks toward a seat, holding a map in his hand. He avoids a FRUITSELLER (who is ad-libbing: “chirimoyas, grenadillas!"). Costin is seated, READING A NEWSPAPER. THE HEADLINE: “SHACKLETON, MURRAY TO SOUTH POLE”. A PICTURE OF SHACKLET and JAMES MURRAY. REMEMBER MR. MURRAY'S FACE. A Woman wit a DOG in a basket stands right near Costin when he moves accommodate Fawcett; the dog bothers him by continually sniffing his ear. Fawcett joins him in the empty seat, holding a map and a smaller piece of paper. He seems concerned, remote.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY COSTIN
dialogues.text: There a problem?

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: We received a cable, in Asuncion. The political situation appears to have worsened and there’s been a change in plan. (to the map) We'll need to redirect our line of approach--our first priority must now be to map the Verde River and find its source. It forms a critical part of the border between Bolivia and Brazil.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY COSTIN
dialogues.text: It’s rather far from here, is it not?

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: It is. (unfolds the map) Our survey route for the river would begin here, at, at--Fazienda Jacobina.  Lost City of Z Green Revision Set 09/30/2015 23A.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY COSTIN
dialogues.text: Yes, I’ve come across it in my reading--it’s meant to be quite enchanting.

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: (looking at his telegram) We're to meet a Corporal Manley there. He’s contacted an Indian guide and hired the rest of our crew. (back to the map) We must chart our progress with as much survey detail as possible. Hopefully any mail from our loved ones will beat us to the spot. (as he folds the map) Time is of the essence. War is at stake and the environment will not be friendly. Costin battles the dog in the basket; it keeps sniffing h ear:

dialogues.speaker: HENRY COSTIN
dialogues.text: We're to stop a war, you and I? The two of us, and a couple of mules?

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: (speechless for a moment; the odds ARE long; then:) Mr. Costin--we’re going to have to depend on each other. Because neither of us will survive this alone.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY COSTIN
dialogues.text: I understand pefectly, sir. However, this DOG will not survive this train ride. (seeing Fawcett reading the journal) What’s that you’re reading?

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: It’s a poem. For our journey. Costin looks over at the book. CLOSE SHOT ON HANDWRITING ABOVE THE TEXT: “TO PERCY, WITH LOVE, NINA.” We TILT DOWN THE TEXT, and we HEAR:  Lost City of Z Green Revision Set 09/30/2015 23B. PERCY FAWCETT (CONT’D) “THERE’S no sense in going further-- it’s the edge of cultivation, So they said, and I believed it--"  20 21 Lost City of Z Buff Revisions (10/25/15) 24.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A wide shot. Our two men look like ants. Over this, we HE the PREVIOUS SCENE continue, and we CUT TO A SERIES OF SH of our men walking in MOUNTAINOUS TERRAIN, then HILLS, th GRASS... Now, NINA FAWCETT’s VOICE. SHE IS READING IT:

dialogues.speaker: NINA FAWCETT, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: “Till a voice, as bad as Conscience, rang interminable changes On one everlasting Whisper day and night repeated--so: ‘Something hidden. Go and find it. Go and look behind the Ranges-- Something lost behind the Ranges. Lost and waiting for you. Go!’”

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A different kind of vegetation--GREEN. The SOUNDS begin t change, too--much less wind, much more active with insect Fawcett is sweating. It is starting to get hot. There are rivulets that all seem to be flowing downhill and gaining steam. Costin stops to take notes in a survey book.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO FAWCETT
dialogues.text: VIEW on the path. Fawcett HACKS AWAY with his machete. He STOPS. SOMETHING SEEMS TO DAWN ON HIM.

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: Mr. Costin-- Then he starts to HACK AWAY AGAIN! With an astonishing furor. WE PAN WITH HIM with each BLOW His FEET are in mud; seeing this: PERCY FAWCETT (CONT’D) Mr. Costin!

dialogues.speaker: HENRY COSTIN
dialogues.text: What is it...? Costin approaches quickly. Finally, a clearing. REVEALING AMAZONIA. A VAST GREEN. The JUNGLE, which engulfs the riverbanks of magnificent AMAZON RIVER. It is beautiful and beguiling, so enormous it fills one with awe.  Lost City of Z Buff Revisions (10/25/15) 242A. Costin comes up behind him, looking over Fawcett’s should He is blown away by the vista. HENRY COSTIN (CONT’D) My God...

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: (almost to himself) It’s even grander than one could have imagined... Stifling the briefest of smiles, Fawcett goes right back putting up a steely front. He starts going through his things. But he cannot hide his excitement. As he rummages PERCY FAWCETT (CONT’D) The manual insists we keep only the essentials now and live off the land, as best we can.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY COSTIN
dialogues.text: Only the essentials, yes. (to himself) Cricket whites, begone... +e HH HH HHH FF + eH  Lost City of Z Buff Revisions (10/25/15) 25.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The camera MOVES THROUGH THE GROWTH, the POINT-OF-VIEW of characters...  23 Lost City of Z Green Revision Set 09/30/2015 26. The SOUNDS of the jungle are loud and yet oddly soothing. should be clear to us from the noises that nature has tak over. BUZZING of unidentifiable creatures...

dialogues.speaker: SERIES OF SHOTS
dialogues.text: Of monkeys and birds and snakes and spiders and frogs... Fawcett, Costin ENTER THE JUNGLE in SILENCE... ONLY THE RUMBLE OF THUNDER... THUNDER, but no RAIN. YET.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fawcett and Costin’s feet sink in mud; a bright YELLOW SN slithers around Fawcett’s feet. Costin’s eyes widen at th sight of it; Fawcett steps over it with studied calm... Sweat pours off their faces; terrible HEAT... SWARMING INSECTS... SAUBA ANTS... TICKS... CHIGGERS... Percy Fawcett BREATHES heavily but HACKS away with his machete. Costin is nearby, slightly ahead, HACKING AWAY a the JUNGLE. Occasionally, Fawcett stops to check a map, takes out his surveying equipment. He calls out:

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: Twenty-nine degrees, 16 minutes, south of the equator.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY COSTIN
dialogues.text: Twenty-nine, and sixteen!

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: (as he starts hacking again) Tell me, Mr. Costin! What induced you to brave this place?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY COSTIN
dialogues.text: Well...I’d studied the natural sciences in Africa, and let’s just say I’d had about enough of the army... (beat; he stops) You know, I’m beginning to miss that dog on the train. (back to hacking) At least I prefer it to all the creatures currently crawling down my neck. SMACK. Fawcett hits his own neck. BUGS, which force the m constantly to be swatting their arms and necks. Then Cost stops. Freezes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: +e * HF

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: +e %  Lost City of Z Green Revision Set 09/30/2015 26A.

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: (as a joke) Every one we kill is one less obstacle in our path! (preoccupied; to self) Some of them are edible, though.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY COSTIN
dialogues.text: Major--

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: (brought back to reality) Yes, Mr. Costin--what is it? (beat) Why are you not proceeding? Costin points down. Fawcett SEES a track of FOOTPRINTS. Looking around, they SPOT:  24 25 Lost City of Z Green Revision Set 09/30/2015 27.

dialogues.speaker: STILL. SILENTLY WATCHING THEM.
dialogues.text: Fawcett stares STRAIGHT INTO THE EYES of ONE OF THE INDIA He then gestures to Costin to KEEP MOVING. He and Costin both put their hands on their guns as they begin to plod slower through the greenery.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE INDIANS OBSERVE FAWCETT AND COSTIN with an astonishin stillness; almost like statues. Fawcett SEES A SEA OF SHRUNKEN HEADS, hanging from trees.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY COSTIN
dialogues.text: (whispered) [Are they] cannibals? Fawcett shakes his head just a touch, as if to say, “I do know”, and signals to Costin to keep walking...

dialogues.speaker: AND THEN FAWCETT AND COSTIN HEAR IT
dialogues.text: At first, it is distant. Then, less faint, and as they progress, one can even tell the piece: from Gaetano Donizetti’s DON PASQUALE. Both men wonder if they’re craz They reach a clearing, slowly but surely making their way through the gauntlet of Indians. And what do they see but

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A THATCHED-ROOF MAKESHIFT STAGE that is serving as an “OP HOUSE”. Here, in the middle of the jungle. Positively surreal. Fawcett turns to the Indians, who are surroundin the two men. In imperfect Portuguese:

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT, (SUBTITLE)
dialogues.text: This is Fazienda Jacobina? (beat) Do you understand? They don’t answer. Instead, they back up, melting away ba into the jungle. Fawcett enters the:  26 27 Lost City of Z Green Revision Set 09/30/2015 28. INT. “OPERA HOUSE” 26 Fawcett surveys the scene. Even though it’s merely a larg clearing, the stage is, oddly, MAGNIFICENTLY APPOINTED wi antiques from Old Europe. They're scattered about. Pathetic space, but you’d never know it listening to the singers and the orchestra. A smattering of people dressed the nines in the audience--wood benches in the middle of rainforest. In the back, Indians sit, quietly, listening to the music bizarre sight indeed. A DIMINUTIVE LATINO MAN dressed in tuxedo approaches Fawcett. In Portuguese:

dialogues.speaker: DIMINUTIVE LATINO MAN, (SUBTITLE)
dialogues.text: (cheerful, almost like an advertisement ) Welcome to the Grand Opera House of beautiful Fazienda Jacobina--thanks to our Baron De Gondoriz and the Inca Mining Company. Do you have your ticket? EXT. FAZIENDA JACOBINA —- RAINY AND THUNDERING NIGHT 27 SUPERIMPOSE: “FAZIENDA JACOBINA PLANTATION, BRAZIL. JUNE, 1906”. The RAIN begins to FALL. HARD. FAR FROM THE ELEGANT PLACE THEY’'D EXPECTED. Fawcett enters this nightmare of a rubb town, with Costin right behind. We PASS TREES with PANS attached to their TRUNKS. LEAKING WHITE FLUID. RUBBER. A DARK-SKINNED MAN is collecting the substance... Fawcett sees that this is not much more than a strip of m with bamboo huts with one notable exception: a RUBBER BAR LARGE HOME, which sits higher on a hill overlooking the c Shockingly miserable. FIRES all over--in cans, campfires, fires incinerating garbage and remains... The presence of the Inca Mining Company is clear, with th corporate logo painted on several of the huts. Fawcett turns, eyes: RAILROAD TRACKS that lead to nowhere BOLIVIAN ARMY OFFICERS line the fronts of the huts, “on t nod,” drunk, all of it. A TEXAN GUNMAN stands out, watchi Running down the “road,” comes: BRITISH OFFICER ARTHUR MANLEY, early twenties, young and cheery but slightly fra Fawcett is still stunned by the misery as Manley begins:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lost City of Z Green Revision Set 09/30/2015 28A.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR MANLEY
dialogues.text: Major Fawcett? Is that you?? It MUST be you! (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lost City of Z Goldenrod Revision Set 10/18/15 29.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR MANLEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (introducing himself) Lance Corporal Manley, sir--liason from the Governor General!

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: How do you do... This is Corporal Costin. Costin nods.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR MANLEY
dialogues.text: You weren't expected for another fortnight! I...hate to be the bearer of bad news, but--we received a telegraph. The Border Commission has cancelled your mission!

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: Cancelled!? What on earth do you mean?!?

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR MANLEY
dialogues.text: What I’ve said, sir! It’s become far too dangerous--there’ve already been more than a few skirmishes between the Bolivians and Brazilians, and they won’t be able to reprovision you as planned!

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: Where is the government office?

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR MANLEY
dialogues.text: Government? (morbid smile) Sir, I’m afraid you've left “government” behind a long time ago. We're grateful for the road!

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: Then Mr. Manley, you send back a telegram--that we will not stand down and we shall proceed as planned! We will CONTINUE and see this through! Manley looks at him for a moment. PERCY FAWCETT (CONT’D) Are you WITH me, Corporal?

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR MANLEY
dialogues.text: Yessir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 28 Lost City of Z Goldenrod Revision Set 10/18/15 29a. As Fawcett looks at Costin, as if to say, “My God, this i terrible place”:

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: Now what about an Indian guide--did * you get us a guide? * ANGLE ON MANLEY as he stops. He turns stone-faced.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR MANLEY
dialogues.text: I...I did, sir. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: Well where is he? * A VOICE, in Portuguese, then English:

dialogues.speaker: A VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Cattle! Coming through!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A LONG LINE of YOUNG MEN, INDIANS, lumbering, HEADS DOWN, CHAINS, through the TOWN. Getting off a SMALL RIVERBOAT that’s beached. Our men are here: Fawcett, Costin, Manley Whispered to Fawcett:

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR MANLEY
dialogues.text: He’s one of them now, sir. Name's Tadjui. The company took him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lost City of Z Goldenrod Revision Set 10/18/15 30. Fawcett steps out to observe. Guards with whips motivate line of men by beating.

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: Who are they?

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR MANLEY
dialogues.text: Slaves, sir.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY COSTIN
dialogues.text: Slaves?!?

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR MANLEY
dialogues.text: Kidnapped from the jungle and brought here for the rubber company.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY COSTIN
dialogues.text: (a sad laugh; sotto) I don’t believe it... Fawcett is appalled too, his face souring instantly. Cost seems in shock.

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: Who’s in charge here? Manley points to the HOUSE, on the HILL:

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR MANLEY
dialogues.text: That would be the Baron de Gondoriz, sir--up there. Fawcett begins to walk toward the house. Costin runs up t Fawcett. In his ear:

dialogues.speaker: HENRY COSTIN
dialogues.text: Where’re you going?

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: He’s got the men we need. Fawcett takes several steps out, into the rain. To Manley PERCY FAWCETT (CONT’D) Bring the Indian up to the house. Tell them we’l1l pay.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR MANLEY
dialogues.text: Yes sir. MANLEY SPEAKS TO THE GUARDS. A BRAZILIAN GUARD CLAPS his HANDS TWICE, yells out some Portuguese. An Indian, TADJUI twenties, in chains, is BUTTED, HARD, by a rifle.  Lost City of Z Goldenrod Revision Set 10/18/15 30A. He does not react. He then steps out from the huge line a though it were voluntary.  29 Lost City of Z Green Revision Set 09/30/2015 31.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BARON DE GONDORIZ, forty, a stocky and imperious sort, si on a CHAIR, surrounded by furs and with a Latino woman serving him drink and food. The Brazilian Infantry is her surrounding (guarding?) him. An INDIAN CRANKS A VICTROLA. DE GONDORIZ’S CHILDREN are here, too, as is his wife. The are dressed in WHITE SUITS and are serious-faced and sile Champagne is poured like water, and food abounds. It’s a real contrast with the street below. Gondoriz is an imposing figure, to be sure. He has a pet JAGUAR, who resides alongside him. The jaguar seems particularly peeved at Costin, for no reason. It growls a him, and Costin’s eyes bulge at the ferocious “pet”...

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: (smiles) * Baron, we're from the British Army. We're very sorry to interrupt your meal. We’re to be venturing down the Rio Verde as peacekeepers and will be in need of some of your men. No response from the Baron. PERCY FAWCETT (CONT’D) In exchange, I’m prepared to tell my government of your cooperation.

dialogues.speaker: BARON DE GONDORIZ
dialogues.text: You are from England?

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: Yes, we are.

dialogues.speaker: BARON DE GONDORIZ
dialogues.text: I’ve been to London, many times. I have seen the opera there--have you * seen my opera house?

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: We did, on our way into town. Congratulations--it was quite * impressive.

dialogues.speaker: BARON DE GONDORIZ
dialogues.text: I have the best singers from all over Europe. And my conductor, he is sick now, but he trained with the great Hubay. (beat) (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lost City of Z Green Revision Set 09/30/2015 31A.

dialogues.speaker: BARON DE GONDORIZ, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Before I come here, I tell myself I will not be a savage. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lost City of Z Goldenrod Revision Set 10/18/15 32.

dialogues.speaker: BARON DE GONDORIZ, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And so I bring civilization to the jungle. I brought my family here, and I raised my children to be cultivated people. I am from Portugal, from Sintra. Someday I will return there. (beat; wistful) Someday. The Texan ENTERS with Tadjui, who is CHAINED AROUND THE N

dialogues.speaker: TEXAN GUNMAN
dialogues.text: You're goin’ upriver, are ya?

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: We are indeed. For surveying.

dialogues.speaker: TEXAN GUNMAN
dialogues.text: (smiles) Well, ain’t nobody comes back from up there. Ever. (looks at the Indian) This the one you’re looking for? Fawcett eyes him for a beat, then:

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: Yes, we'd like very much to employ him.

dialogues.speaker: TEXAN GUNMAN
dialogues.text: He’s a rebellious son of a bitch, I’1ll tell you that. He’s been beaten. And he'll be beaten again.

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: All the better I should take him off your hands, then. Tadjui, Fawcett exchange glares. Fawcett approaches Tadju PERCY FAWCETT (CONT’D) Do you speak English?

dialogues.speaker: TEXAN GUNMAN
dialogues.text: We taught ‘em. [To] Civilize ‘em.

dialogues.speaker: TADJUIL
dialogues.text: I am speaking little.

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: And you know the river? Tadjui nods.  Lost City of Z Goldenrod Revision Set 10/18/15 32A. PERCY FAWCETT (CONT’D) (to Baron De Gondoriz) What will you take for him and any four men he chooses?

dialogues.speaker: TEXAN GUNMAN
dialogues.text: You got money?

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: I--promise highly favorable treatment from my country.

dialogues.speaker: BARON DE GONDORIZ
dialogues.text: Your country is not what it used to be. Fawcett is momentarily at a loss for words.  Lost City of Z Green Revision Set 09/30/2015 33. BARON DE GONDORIZ (CONT’D) It offends you to negotiate with me. I see this is true.

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: No--

dialogues.speaker: BARON DE GONDORIZ
dialogues.text: Please--do not embarrass yourself. I prefer to speak openly when it is possible; do you not? (before Fawcett can answer: ) You come here to make maps. And why is that? So that there may be peace. What is peace? Peace means my business will flourish--I will flourish. You may hold your nose when you accept my help, yet without my help you know you cannot succeed. The closer you will look at the truth, the more disgusted you will grow--not at me but at yourself. In the end, peace means only that nothing will change. So I will help you because you will make sure nothing will change. Then De Gondoriz notices something. Points to Costin’s rifle. BARON DE GONDORIZ (CONT’D) That is very beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: TEXAN GUNMAN
dialogues.text: There ain’t a whole lot of those in these parts, Baron. A fine piece. Costin seems reluctant. Fawcett looks to Costin, takes hi aside. Costin is impatient, whispers to Fawcett:

dialogues.speaker: HENRY COSTIN
dialogues.text: It's a family heirloom, sir. It’s a Henry--my father used it against the Zulu.

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: Consider it your gift to the King.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY COSTIN
dialogues.text: You do realize this goes to pay for a slave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He HH HHH HH HH HF HHH HH HK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lost City of Z Green Revision Set 09/30/2015 33A.

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: (to the others) Would you excuse me, please. Fawcett leads Costin outside:

dialogues.speaker: A30
dialogues.text: Under an overhang, on the porch. Starts quiet, but heated

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: We'll hire as many of them as we can and set them free when we’re done. Fawcett starts to turn back; Costin stops him:

dialogues.speaker: HENRY COSTIN
dialogues.text: When we’re DONE? Are we slaveowners now?

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: No. As I say, we'll pay them and treat them as any other in our party. (beat) It’s the most we can do under the circumstances.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY COSTIN
dialogues.text: I‘1l not dirty my hands just because it suits our needs.

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: Would your hands be any cleaner if we left them here to die? We’re the only hope they’ve got. We need them and we'll take them with us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: +e * HF

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 30 Lost City of Z Buff Revisions (10/25/15) 34-35.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY COSTIN
dialogues.text: But we’ve got to report it--

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: (loses a bit of patience) To whom, Corporal? To WHOM? Have you taken a look around--do you see where we are? (beat) I promise you, their story shall not go untold if we survive. I promise you that. Costin realizes Fawcett is right. He steps forward, and swallowing his pride, he unslings his rifle. Muttering:

dialogues.speaker: HENRY COSTIN
dialogues.text: Just as it’s always been. One group gets the sugar, the other one gets the shit. Costin walks past Fawcett, reentering:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Costin approaches the Texas Gunman as Percy reenters:

dialogues.speaker: HENRY COSTIN
dialogues.text: (holding up the rifle; a hint of sarcasm) Here. Is your very own handmade rifle. A Martini-Henry. Well done. The Texas Gunman takes the rifle, looks at it, aims it. T passes it to the Baron. The Baron looks to Costin, Fawcet aims, pulls the trigger. CLICK. Then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fawcett stands by the river. Ties a rope for a boat. WIDE TO REVEAL: THE INDIAN TADJUI, and he has brought FOUR OTH LEJO INDIANS with him. They work on the rafts, passing th drink kachasa between them. TADJUI, shirtless, has SCARS his BACK, which Fawcett notices.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A SACK OF MAIL is dropped at Fawcett’s feet by a local. H sifts through it, finding a letter from his WIFE.

dialogues.speaker: FLASH CUT TO
dialogues.text: +e HH OH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 33 Lost City of Z Buff Revisions (10/25/15)34-35A.

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: As SHE SITS AT HER DESK, writing. Their SON JACK, in the background. We STILL HEAR the SOUNDS OF THE JUNGLE.

dialogues.speaker: CUT BACK TO
dialogues.text: He is about to open it. Merely pockets it. He then walks over to Tadjui.

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: Can you show me where we’re to pitch camp tonight? Tadjui traces his finger along the river on the map, then stops several inches into a blank area. HE TRACES THE SHA WITH HIS FINGER. SEEMS TO KNOW EVERY CURVE.

dialogues.speaker: TADJUL
dialogues.text: Long time on the river before stop. Fawcett looks out, at the RIVER...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We then SEE: A GROUP OF SCRUFFY MEN, building rafts with sticks and twine, shoving estopa (beaten palm fiber) into cracks in the rafts. Costin is working with the group, bu

dialogues.speaker: HENRY COSTIN
dialogues.text: This’s our party then? (Manley nods, so:) It’s a bloody desperate lot you've got us.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR MANLEY
dialogues.text: They’re as dependable as can be found here. I’m the only one who'll pay them. The MEN: DAN, a flamboyant drunk, does a dance as he load the raft. WILLIS, a capable Jamaican cook, loads the FOOD in large baskets. THREE OTHER WHITE MEN, DESPERADOS, who look like Jurgen Prochnow’s more frightening brothers. Mustachioed. One is an Austrian named URQUHART. Arthur Manley has loaded an ACCORDION onto the boat. Fawcett ste near the men, securing a parcel loaded improperly. He interrupts one of them trying to tighten:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: eH HHH + eH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lost City of Z Buff Revisions (10/25/15)34-35B.

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: (as he tightens the rope; then looks at all of them) The river shall be our home for the next two years and we’ll not turn back. Twelve hours a day and no less. MUSIC UP: A SWEET AND MELANCHOLY SONG, PLAYED BY INDIANS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 34 35 Lost City of Z Buff Revisions (10/25/15) 36.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fawcett, Costin, Manley, Willis, Dan, Urquhart, the silen and tall DESPERADOS, Tadjui and the 4 LEJO INDIANS push o on TWO LARGE RAFTS. Three SMALL HOUNDS ACCOMPANY THE MEN. A CROWD has assembled around the group as they depart. Th Indians sing a local folk song as they shove off. MANY OF THE BRAZILIAN INFANTRY set off their Winchesters into the to celebrate. The INDIAN WOMEN wave their goodbyes... The BARON and his TEXAN GUNMAN eye the men from higher up The TEXAN DRAWS HIS FINGER ACROSS HIS NECK, smiling... Fawcett averts his gaze, looks down at his MAP. We TILT D to SEE THE WORD: “UNEXPLORED”. The river is READY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The group drifts on their rafts through a cavernous space with eerie plateaus of the Ricardo Franco Hills on both s of the rafts. FAWCETT’S MEN push with the bamboo poles through the water as FAWCETT SURVEYS. The camera PANS PAS his notes on flora and fauna and temperature and barometr readings, all painstakingly done. His attention, however, begins to be divided between his surveying and the astonishing scenery around him. BEAUTIFUL RAINBOW-COLORED FISH swim in the river next to enormous EELS. DAN turns to COSTIN, re the eels:

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: They’11 shock you to death, those things. Other fish, the candiru-- they’1l swim right up your johnson-- so don’t never be letting loose in the river.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY COSTIN
dialogues.text: (wide smile; sarcastic) Thank you so very much for that information. Costin then reflexively touches his crotch. It is SILENT, Fawcett turns to Manley, and, half-jokingly:

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: Can you play? (beat) We don’t want to be driven mad by the silence. Fawcett points to Manley’s accordion case.  36 Lost City of Z Green Revision Set 09/30/2015 37.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR MANLEY
dialogues.text: Right, sir. Manley takes out his ACCORDION. The sounds ECHO, all over the space. MANLEY PLAYS a BRITISH WAR SONG. The accordion sounds like a full orchestra here...

dialogues.speaker: EERIE QUIET. SURVEYING BOOKS
dialogues.text: slowly but surely. TILT UP: Fawcett is taking photographs The Indians are assembled in one corner of one of the raf Tadjui plays a ZAMPONA (the Incan PAN FLUTE). Fawcett finishes his work, and folding the tripod legs, observes the mailbag. He reaches into his pocket and open up the LETTER from his wife. Unwrapping it, a PICTURE FAL OUT. A BABY, along with JACK and NINA. A NEWBORN with his family. Costin picks it up:

dialogues.speaker: HENRY COSTIN
dialogues.text: A new one, Major? A boy?

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: It must be so. Fawcett takes the picture, looks at it.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY COSTIN
dialogues.text: Congratulations.

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: Thank you, Mr. Costin. He then POCKETS THE PHOTO. Costin eyes him. FAWCETT TAKES THE PHOTO OUT AGAIN. PERCY FAWCETT (CONT’D) The boy’s name is “Brian”.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY COSTIN
dialogues.text: Major, if I may venture a suggestion-- Fawcett sees Costin point to the photo, then to his pocke Fawcett stares at Costin, then, deciding Costin is right, NODS ONCE AND PUTS THE PHOTO BACK in his POCKET:

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: Right, Mr. Costin...  37 Lost City of Z Goldenrod Revision Set 10/18/15 38.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two RAFTS travel one right behind the other, as the overgrowth gets lower and lower over the banks of this narrowing AMAZON TRIBUTARY. They approach an abandoned steamer on the river: a German ship, the ANTONIA. From Hamburg, painted on its back. As this is happening, Urquhart is on the flat raft, attempting to catch fish with the net. With his thick accent:

dialogues.speaker: URQUHART
dialogues.text: Nothing again! Not ONE fish! It’s a desert--a green desert!

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: Pull it in, we’ll try further down. Fawcett steps onto the raft, to help Urquhart pull the ne in. SIMULTANEOUS, on the batelon:

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR MANLEY
dialogues.text: What on earth’s she doing all the way out here?

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: (turning back) She’s come to load rubber, no doubt. (to Costin) Get us closer, Mr. Costin! Maybe they’1l have news, or food for us!

dialogues.speaker: HENRY COSTIN
dialogues.text: Looks abandoned to my eye! As he steers, Costin NOTICES a BLACK SPOT IN HIS SKIN. UH OH.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: (as they get closer, seeing “HAMBURG” ) It’s German! I say we go aboard and have a beer--I bet they have real German beer, fresh from the cask! But, as they get closer, they see something macabre: A LO MAN, maybe dead, maybe not, sits on the top of the boat, still. Nude. Staring at them, not moving. The hull’s riddled with arrows.  Lost City of Z Goldenrod Revision Set 10/18/15 38A.

dialogues.speaker: URQUHART
dialogues.text: Is he ALIVE? Try to talk to him! See where they are from in--  38 39 Lost City of Z Green Revision Set 09/30/2015 39. And he FREEZES. FAWCETT, next to him, is momentarily bewildered. THEN: HE SEES AN ARROW in his BACK. URQUHART SPINS OFF THE RAFT, TANGLED IN THE FISHING NET. ALL OF A SUDDEN: FLYING ARROWS. FEROCIOUS. AND SPEARS. Coming from the trees. We can’t SEE any other INDIANS, bu they’re there, in the forest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The flurry does not stop. All the men duck for cover. PANIC. The arrows come with tremendous and frightening force, some of them penetrating inches deep into the raft wood. Costin pushes with his long BAMBOO pole. The rafts begin drift in an altogether different direction, away from the arrows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fawcett IS YANKED INTO THE RIVER by Urquhart, who is dyin and has tangled the two of them in the fishing net. The arrows continue to fly. The RAFT TILTS DANGEROUSLY with the weight shift.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Costin tumbles as well, but stays aboard, making sure THE MAPBOOKS survive. He loses his JOURNAL book and other personal items in the mayhem, however, as the bag of photographs falls overboard:

dialogues.speaker: HENRY COSTIN
dialogues.text: God damn it! GET THEM OUT! * Manley attempts to retrieve the net-- *

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fawcett is underwater, with Urquhart atop him as the two

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: struggle with the rope. FAWCETT untangles his feet from t rope and pulls himself up, attempting to grab Urquhart as rises to the surface. One thing gets in the way: PIRANHAS . Piranhas start nipping at the men. The piranhas focus on Urquhart, who was cut by the arrow--the blood is attracti them. The feeding has begun to turn into a FRENZY. Getting pinched by the fish as well--though with nowhere the ferocity, for he has no open wound--Fawcett is forced abandon Urquhart and PULLS HIMSELF ALONG THE ROPE.  Lost City of Z Green Revision Set 09/30/2015 39A. COSTIN GRABS FAWCETT and helps pull him onto the RAFT.  40 4l Lost City of Z Buff Revisions (10/25/15) 40-43.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fawcett gets aboard the raft with more than a couple of piranhas still attached to his arms and legs. Fawcett and Costin swat away the piranhas and, courageously braving t still-constant stream of arrows, tries to get Urquhart aboard:

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: Come on, pull! Manley and the others help, with Tadjui looking on. Fawce finally succeeds in pulling Urquhart up, onto the raft. And he is DEAD. His lower half has been completely devour by the piranhas...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The RAFTS FINALLY PASS THE FLURRY OF ARROWS AND SPEARS. T last FLURRY OF SPEARS hit near the raft without incident. ANGLE ON FAWCETT. Out of breath and spent beyond words. H SEES his PERSONAL EFFECTS--the LETTER, the FAMILY PHOTOGRAPHS, on the raft and soaked. They’d been spilled during the chaos. PERCY FAWCETT (CONT’D) Thank you for your aid, Mr. Costin. Costin nods. Fawcett’s face wrinkles in anguished recognition of his articles’ damage. HE COLLECTS HIS THIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rain. Silence. Gloom. Fear. All stumble, quietly, as they help pull the boats across shallow water. FAWCETT is stil alert. The MAPBOOKS are getting more and more completed.. Virtually no more food in the containers. The hounds rumm alongside the rafts, sniffing at anything they can lick o chew. MORE BUGS: flies, mosquitos, spiders, maggots in the skin Costin, who has now grown very sick with fever, shivers i the rain as he can barely walk. Manley VOMITS black fluid Hunched by the edge of the raft:

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR MANLEY
dialogues.text: I...I’m sick...I think I’ve malaria... Perhaps the sun shall bake the fever out of me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: + eH  Lost City of Z Buff Revisions (10/25/15)40-43A. Dan is hallucinating; he mutters about his hallucinations aloud:

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: Months on the river! And--so many beautiful flowers... Dan has MAGGOTS in his ARM.

dialogues.speaker: DAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: My maggots... Are they...they’re my friends! He SMILES. Fawcett sees Costin, who hides his own skin blemish, on h arm. Costin makes eye contact, pulling down his sleeve:

dialogues.speaker: HENRY COSTIN
dialogues.text: It’s nothing at all... Percy moves to Tadjui:

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: Are we close?

dialogues.speaker: TADJUL
dialogues.text: Many week to go. The river still strong. Fawcett looks at his men, then back to Tadjui:

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: We won’t survive another attack. If there are more dangerous tribes ahead--

dialogues.speaker: TADJUL
dialogues.text: The river is death. (beat) But you will see--many people live here once. Beautiful city of gold and maize. Even older than English. With roads and bridges. Percy SNAPS to attention. He looks at Tadjui as though he completely mad.

dialogues.speaker: TADJUI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Deep, in the forest. All gold. It blaze, like fire. Fawcett turns away, devastated by the prospect that Tadju also going mad. Under his breath:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 42 Lost City of Z Buff Revisions (10/25/15)40-43B.

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: Christ...

dialogues.speaker: TADJUL
dialogues.text: Conquistador try to find it, many try. But the white man never find it... Reaching for his RIFLE, Fawcett LOADS IT. POCKETS SPARE

dialogues.speaker: TADJUI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I feel sorry for you, English! Soon I am free! For the Espanol and you, there is no escape from jungle--only death!

dialogues.speaker: WILLIS
dialogues.text: The river's coming back! Pitching camp! UP AHEAD: A CLEARING.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The members of the group sit with their rifles aimed into darkness. They see the TWINKLES from the eyes of animals into that dark. The noises of the jungle frighten them beyond belief. Then the jungle goes SILENT. Then the nois pick up again. Terrifying. Even the hounds are petrified. Fawcett sits near the fire, rifle aimed outward into the dark. Costin, without his Martini-Henry rifle, is covered blankets. HUSHED, SHIVERING.

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: (to Costin, whispered) Mr. Costin? Mr. Costin, are you alert?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY COSTIN
dialogues.text: (a morbid joke as he shivers) I am, feeling just fit as a fiddle. How you have managed to avoid any maladies is utterly beyond me.

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: (approaches Costin, still whispered) Even the Indian’s gone mad now. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: + eH +e * HF

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He HHH HF OF HHH FHF HHH OF + eH  Lost City of Z Buff Revisions (10/25/15)40-43c.

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He’s been going on about gold cities. We should be prepared for anything.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY COSTIN
dialogues.text: Then I would suggest you keep your firearm close and ready, sir.

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: (nods; then) I'd like you to read this to me. If you can. Fawcett reaches into his pocket. Takes out many envelopes Sifts through the letters. Hands one to Costin: PERCY FAWCETT (CONT’D) We may be at the end now and I believe it’s time. (beat) I'm afraid it’s quite unbearable for me to read it myself. Would you please? Costin wordlessly takes it from Fawcett, staring at Fawce

dialogues.speaker: HENRY COSTIN
dialogues.text: (beat) “My dearest Puggy--”

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: Feel free to summarize.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY COSTIN
dialogues.text: I was hoping you'd say that... She's moved the family to Devon, and in your absence is promoting your name. Your new son Brian is doing well. And your older son Jack is excelling, she says in all ways... Fawcett is devastated hearing about all this. Starts to t up. Costin holds up the letter: HENRY COSTIN (CONT’D) Shall I continue? Fawcett gently takes the LETTER from Costin’s hand. HE PU THE LETTER IN THE FIRE. Fawcett WATCHES IT BURN FOR A MOMENT. We SEE the SCRIBBLE WORDS ON THE PAPER as they get CONSUMED BY THE FIRE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: + eH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: +e % ee

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lost City of Z Buff Revisions (10/25/15)40-43D. Fawcett watches the letter burn. He shakes his head at th preposterousness:

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: I see my son’s face in my dreams now. (sotto) What a mistake to come here... He GRABS HIS HEAD, each palm of his hand on each side of head. Closes his eyes in ANGUISH. As Fawcett wipes tears from his face:

dialogues.speaker: HENRY COSTIN
dialogues.text: Major--I’m not one for speeches. And if I should die here, I know my name dies with me. But I have fought as a soldier, and I have tasted victory. What have you tasted--besides your unrealized dreams? If you allow yourself to perish here, you will have achieved nothing. Now that my fever has come on, I may well not survive. Indeed, I am of little use in my current state. But you must persevere. (a sardonic smile) And may I add, if you should manage to take me with you, I’1l not protest.

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: (he smiles as the words sink in; checks his chronometer) I shall endeavor to do both, Mr. Costin. (louder, to the group) Six hours rest. Dawn’s approaching. Dan, collapsed at the base of a tree nearby, begs Fawcett

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: Please, Mr. Fawcett--I’m not fit. I, I think I might be near my end in this bloody hell.

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: You can walk, can you not? Dan can, but does not answer. Fawcett takes out his BIG KNIFE. Moves up to Dan, puts his blade to Dan’s throat: +e HF FF +e % He HH HHH HHH HH HH HH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: +e HF

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lost City of Z Buff Revisions (10/25/15)40-43E. PERCY FAWCETT (CONT’D) If we die, we'll die on our feet-- unless you prefer the knife.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 43 Lost City of Z Buff Revisions (10/25/15) 44,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DRIZZLING RAIN. CLOSE SHOT ON FAWCETT. HE’S GOT A WIDE-EY STARE, with DARK and DEEP-SET EYES. Fawcett may be frail, but he is at least mentally in cont of himself--unlike the others. Costin is either unconscio or DEAD.

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: Mr. Costin...? Mr. Costin? Fawcett is visibly upset that Costin does not answer. Tad prays aloud... Manley is shivering terribly and covered w maggots; HE IS STICKING HIS TONGUE OUT, TO CATCH THE RAIN IT FALLS FOR HYDRATION. Dan is muttering to himself, alou he also sticks out his tongue for the rain’s water. Even dogs have gone totally lethargic, and the carcass of one them slides into the river. Willis rummages through the food baskets. Nothing but a couple of rotten fruit. He begins to cry:

dialogues.speaker: WILLIS
dialogues.text: No more food! Ain’t nothing left-- NOTHING--— ONLY A ROTTEN BANANA REMAINS. Willis charges for it; Dan he FIGHT OVER IT BRIEFLY. SEEING this: Fawcett gets up, approaches the men:

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: Stop it--get--we’re not savages! Tadjui stops playing the zampona. He stands.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: We're leaving our bones here! And for what?!? A map??? We’re not even lookin’ for gold! Dan STEPS BACK, ARMED. He approaches Fawcett, dangerously close, with his RIFLE POINTED AT FAWCETT:  44 Lost City of Z Buff Revisions (10/25/15) 45.

dialogues.speaker: DAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: There could be war already and we wouldn’t even know it! Have you ever considered that?! Dan turns to the others. He is ready to CHARGE. MUTINY?!?

dialogues.speaker: DAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Even if we get there, we ain’t makin’ it back with nothing in our bellies! (turning back to Fawcett, still directed to others) Let’s have at him! Fawcett looks at the others. With the exception of Costin and Manley, both of whom now LOOK UNCONSCIOUS if NOT DEAD they all SEEM READY TO CHARGE AT HIM. Fawcett seems to st himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dan TAKES A STEP FORWARD, and Fawcett’s eyes widen. Then

dialogues.speaker: FAWCETT CATCHES SIGHT OF COSTIN--WHO HAS TURNED TOWARD US
dialogues.text: HOLDING HIS PISTOL! (Dan has his back to Costin and canno see.) Dan takes a step TOWARD Fawcett, ready to do away with hi when--COSTIN FIRES! Dan CURLS OVER with a STUNNING VIOLEN BLOOD POURING FROM HIS EAR. Dan CUPS his ear with his han howling in pain.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY COSTIN
dialogues.text: The next one I’1l1 put between your eyes! AND THEN: wordlessly, TADJUI POINTS. The others turn to look, one by one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: EMERGING: THE SOURCE OF THE VERDE RIVER. The men are froz in awe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The water dribbles from a small cliff, down into the base the river. It is a beautiful sight. Fawcett slowly takes out his surveying equipment and the camera.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY COSTIN
dialogues.text: (proud, almost giddy) We made it! No one’s ever been here before! No one! NO ONE!!!  Lost City of Z Buff Revisions (10/25/15) 45A.

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: Prepare for the group photograph, Mr. Costin... Costin takes the camera and plants it on a TRIPOD for THE GROUP PHOTO, but he is so depleted he can barely move his limbs. The others weakly get into position for the photo. Dan weeps as he slides into his position.  Lost City of Z Green Revision Set 09/30/2015 46. Manley looks around, then calls out:

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR MANLEY
