dialogues.text: Major... We've, we've lost the Indian-- FAWCETT SPINS AROUND. TADJUI IS INDEED GONE. As are the * other INDIANS. Fawcett sees footprints, leading off into jungle. Manley seems primed to track the footprints when Fawcett stops him.

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: Mr. Manley! He got us here, didn’t * he...? Fawcett hears a subtle CRUNCHING NOISE in the brush. ALL STARTLED. Takes a quiet step forward. FAWCETT holds his finger to his lips--"QUIET!” And then d into the brush. Costin approaches, sees something, or at least thinks he does. Turns to Manley, who is standing ne to him. Whispering:

dialogues.speaker: HENRY COSTIN
dialogues.text: Am I dreaming it? *

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR MANLEY
dialogues.text: No--I see it too. * LONG-LENS CLOSE SHOT on a DEER. SEVERAL YARDS AWAY, about 30, deeper into the forest. The deer is oblivious. Fawcett has his gun trained on it. The men now surround Fawcett with the gun. Fawcett is silently getting ready to fire. The deer is chewing grass Manley is praying to himself. Dan, also praying but aloud is still panicking:

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: Please... Lord... It’s our only chance!

dialogues.speaker: WILLIS
dialogues.text: (whispered) Shut up! CLOSE SHOT ON FAWCETT’S EYE as he readies the shot. CLOSE SHOT ON THE DEER--which seems to spot FAWCETT.

dialogues.speaker: THE DEER GALLOPS AWAY JUST AS FAWCETT FIRES THE GUN. A TU
dialogues.text: OF SMOKE. The deer is gone.  45 Lost City of Z Green Revision Set 09/30/2015 47.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: (breaking down) God damn you, you missed! We'll starve for sure! Without answering, Fawcett charges up to where the deer w

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The deer is here. On the ground. DEAD. Fawcett hit it square in the head. The others have now joined him around the animal.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY COSTIN
dialogues.text: I couldn't have done that better myself. The men start to drag the deer to the riverbank. And onto the raft.

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: Start a fire. We’ll-- Then FAWCETT FREEZES. He has SEEN SOMETHING. WHITE AS A GHOST. Costin approaches, sees it too. WE CUT TO REVEAL: COVERED WITH MOSS, unmistakably: a SMAL STATUE, perched atop a ROCK.

dialogues.speaker: FAWCETT WALKS TO IT. REACHES OUT. TOUCHES IT.
dialogues.text: THEN TAKES SEVERAL STEPS FORWARD, as if to continue the MISSION DEEPER INTO THE JUNGLE. HE SEES: PAINTINGS, on ROCKS. He looks to the ground, SPOTTING SHARDS OF POTTERY, STATUES. He SEEMS ALMOST LIKE RABID DOG. Under his breath:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PERCY FAWCETT (CONT’D) Good Christ--

dialogues.speaker: HE SPINS AROUND TO THE OTHERS
dialogues.text: PERCY FAWCETT (CONT’D) There’s...pottery--right beneath our feet! Fawcett pockets it, starts to dig. PERCY FAWCETT (CONT’D) It’s all over--deep, in the ground...  46 Lost City of Z Green Revision Set 09/30/2015 48. Then he takes a few more steps. Fawcett runs his fingers along a ROCK PAINTING. PERCY FAWCETT (CONT’D) (sotto) My God, he was right-- (beat) The Indian was right-- He starts putting all the pottery in his pockets... RUMMAGING IN THE MUD, he is covered like a PRIMATE: PERCY FAWCETT (CONT’D) (to the others) The Indian spoke of this! (beat) He was bloody right! HE WAS BLOODY

dialogues.speaker: RIGHT
dialogues.text: (charges up to Costin) Mr. Costin, you said no one’d ever been here before--

dialogues.speaker: HENRY COSTIN
dialogues.text: (stunned) Yes, Chief. I--I did--

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: No white man had, Mr. Costin. NO

dialogues.speaker: WHITE MEN
dialogues.text: A BEAT as Costin lets it sink in. FAWCETT TURNS BACK TO T BRUSH. A HOUND FOLLOWS HIM. Through some vines, he SEES a carving in stone--or so he thinks. About to reach out to The hound leads the way a bit--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JUNGLE, RIGHT TOWARD THEM! It TAKES the DOG in its TEETH.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fawcett and the men BOLT, some yelling in fear, away from panther.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE SHOT ON FAWCETT as the mouth of the RIVER RECEDES..

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: We'll follow the watershed and pray it brings us out. (beat) If we ever make it back, the world must know what we’ve found here...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lost City of Z Buff Revisions (10/25/15) 48A.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY COSTIN
dialogues.text: That deer better have more meat on its bones than we do...  47 48 Lost City of Z Green Revision Set 09/30/2015 49.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A magnificent building in busy downtown La Paz. BUSTLING.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A group of very comfortable British soldiers are at work their desks as one BRITISH SECRETARY types at the front d Smiles, joking. Then they STOP. Percy Fawcett walks into the building. He looks and smell like hell, filthy and unshaven and shaking like a leaf fr malnutrition. Hair completely out of control, his beard a epic length. He approaches an official (CECIL GOSLING) at the front de The official, whose nose crinkles up--presumably at the stench of Fawcett--seems bewildered. Fawcett SHAKES LIKE LEAF; is he mad?

dialogues.speaker: CECIL GOSLING
dialogues.text: May I...help you, sir?

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: Tell me please--is there war, between Bolivia and Brazil? I’11l fight if I’m needed.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL GOSLING
dialogues.text: (baffled) War? No, sir--there’s no war. Is there something we might do for you?

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: My name is Major Percy Fawcett. If you could, please contact my family through the Royal Geographical Society, in London. SLAM! Fawcett DUMPS a series of frayed map notebooks on t desk. He also EMPTIES HIS POCKETS OF POTTERY SHARDS. A BRITISH OFFICIAL ("SIMON BEAUCLERK”) with his back to us overhears this. He seems interested, turns. Approaches. Meanwhile, Fawcett is hurriedly throwing everything on th desk: PERCY FAWCETT (CONT’D) I’ve the maps here, they’re, they’re all completed... (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lost City of Z Green Revision Set 09/30/2015 49A. PERCY FAWCETT (CONT’D) And, and I found these, these bits of pottery, and statues, in the jungle--a great discovery...to be pursued...  Lost City of Z Green Revision Set 09/30/2015 50.

dialogues.speaker: SIMON BEAUCLERK
dialogues.text: Major Fawcett? Fawcett struggles even to nod:

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: Yes...? ENTERING, almost crawling in now, behind Fawcett: COSTIN, MANLEY, WILLIS.

dialogues.speaker: SIMON BEAUCLERK
dialogues.text: I believe I got your orders on my desk just last week. You were supposed to arrive here in July
Fawcett looks up, sees a calendar on the wall: “AUGUST.”

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: (devastated) I'm, I’m so very sorry, it’s August... We did the best we could- -most members of our party did not survive.

dialogues.speaker: SIMON BEAUCLERK
dialogues.text: Major, it’s August 1907. You're eleven months early. You've mapped the entire Verde tributary a year ahead of schedule.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HE AND THE OTHER OFFICERS ARE ASTONISHED. Another British Officer, seeing how frail Fawcett looks, runs to get a ch and positions it right behind Fawcett:

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: I can stand, thank you. A whole host of officers now seem to realize what’s going and begin to gather around Fawcett.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL GOSLING
dialogues.text: Sir, should you like a bed? Some food, or a bath perhaps?

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: Yes. For ALL of us.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL GOSLING
dialogues.text: Yessir. Of course.  49 Lost City of Z Green Revision Set 09/30/2015 51.

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: And I'd like you to send a telegram to my wife, Mrs. Nina Agnes Fawcett --HELL VERDE CONQUERED. And then FAWCETT’S EYES ROLL BACK INTO HIS HEAD. He COLLAPSES... PRE-LAP a MARCHING BAND playing an UPBEAT SONG:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is late afternoon and the port is PACKED with people. band plays a MARCH and the mood is an absolute celebratio A BOAT is at the DOCK. OFF THE BOAT COMES PERCY FAWCETT. CHEER. A HERO’S WELCOME. He LOOKS THROUGH THE CROWD. He looks for someone... The CROWD TRIES TO TOUCH HIM, DOES TOUCH HIM. PUSHING HER WAY toward him: NINA FAWCETT, HOLDING A BABY. It’s BRIAN. Her other HAND holds the hand of her son JACK now significantly older. To the children, with a huge smi

dialogues.speaker: NINA FAWCETT
dialogues.text: There’s your father--everyone’s here for him! He’s the hero of the day! PERCY makes his way through the crowd and the two finally spot each other. He PUSHES. She PUSHES. As the shoving continues, a RANDOM MAN AT THE PORT:

dialogues.speaker: RANDOM MAN AT THE PORT
dialogues.text: Major Fawcett! You've raised the Union Jack for all the world to see!!! Fawcett finally gets to her. A beat of silence as they lo at each other, then:

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: (through happy tears) You’re the most beautiful woman I’ve ever seen.

dialogues.speaker: NINA FAWCETT
dialogues.text: You're different. And yet exactly the same.  50 51 Lost City of Z White 7/31/15 52. THEY EMBRACE, KISS. Intimate, through tears:

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: I’ve missed you so much--though God knows, I tried not to... They separate. Fawcett looks down. Jack looks at him with total dispassion:

dialogues.speaker: JACK FAWCETT
dialogues.text: Are you my father?

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: I am indeed, my son! Percy hugs him so very tightly and bursts into tears BUT: JACK HAS VIRTUALLY NO REACTION. PERCY REGISTERS THIS; the boy COULD CARE LESS. It is AWKWARD; PERCY’S SMILE DISAPPEARS. So: standing next to Percy is Brian:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PERCY FAWCETT (CONT’D) And this is my little Brian...? My little Brian!! Come here--come!

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: CLOSE SHOT of an INVITATION. The Royal Geographical Socie invitation, to a dinner celebrating Maj. Percy Fawcett. A the home of the Honorable Mr. James Murray...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beautiful structure. A PARTY, with MUSIC.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two receiving lines: one for women, one for men. PERCY AN NINA FAWCETT enter and immediately are greeted by members their own gender, but extremely WARMLY. (This should be i marked contrast to the film’s opening gala.) Fawcett is T TOAST OF THE TOWN. Sir George Goldie SWALLOWS him up, mov him away from Nina. Nina and Percy exchange bemused looks he is pulled away:

dialogues.speaker: SIR GEORGE GOLDIE
dialogues.text: Percy! Come... Meet our host. He is most anxious to meet you. I must say, he is the most marvelous of men. A person of considerable... resources. And of the finest stock.  Lost City of Z Blue Revision Set 8/19/15 53. The DOOR OPENS, REVEALING:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A magnificent room, with long tables and sofas and beauti paintings on the walls. ALL MEN, dressed in black tie. Th top brass of the RGS: Sir John Scott Keltie, Sir George Goldie, others. AND: MR. JAMES MURRAY, fifty-five and dashing, with grayi hair and a well-trimmed mustache. We remember him somehow the cover of that newspaper! Cigars are smoked. The air is thick with wealth and decor It could not be further from the jungle here, as SERVANTS PLACE CUPS with SAUCERS DOWN IN PERFECT SYNCHRONIZED RHYT

dialogues.speaker: JAMES MURRAY
dialogues.text: Major Fawcett--what an honor! What an HONOR! Everyone's talking about your mission. Just remarkable, a real triumph!

dialogues.speaker: SIR GEORGE GOLDIE
dialogues.text: Major, this is Mr. James Murray.

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: How do you do.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES MURRAY
dialogues.text: Very well, very well... Welcome to the inner circle! Murray puts his arm around Fawcett, cheerfully.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The men and women, seated around a large and elegant tabl

dialogues.speaker: JAMES MURRAY
dialogues.text: I read your editorial in the Times this morning--about the slave trade in the Americas. Truly enlightened. Poor savages.

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: The native does deserve our sympathy. We’ve only just scratched the surface in Amazonia.  Lost City of Z Blue Revision Set 8/19/15 53A.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES MURRAY
dialogues.text: Yes, certainly, there’s much more territory to be charted! (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lost City of Z White 7/31/15 54.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES MURRAY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You know, I am a biologist and explorer myself--I was second-in- command to Mr. Shackelton on his Antartica expedition.

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: I don’t think there’s anyone here who’s not well aware of your achievements, Mr. Murray. You've distinguished yourself with great bravery.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES MURRAY
dialogues.text: (a bit of false modesty) Oh, it’s nothing compared to Amazonia. Surveying the Amazon's always been a great goal of mine.

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: I would hope the RGS continues its pursuits. But I believe mapmaking should be of secondary interest now. I witnessed many archeological sightings of great significance. Some guy interrupts MURRAY. He is WILLIAM BARCLAY, thirty one (more from him later):

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM BARCLAY
dialogues.text: Mr. Murray! Murray turns to talk to him; Sir John Scott Keltie moves To Fawcett; sotto:

dialogues.speaker: SIR JOHN SCOTT KELTIE
dialogues.text: My friend--your recent exploits have opened every door to you--so I would suggest keeping such sightings to yourself. Of course, no one here would dispute you believed you saw it. But a trip like that--very hard on the mind. Very hard. The evening changes now for Fawcett. He DARKENS.

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: Sir John, my mind is perfectly fit-- and thank heavens, still open. Fawcett steps away from Keltie and eyes JAMES MURRAY, hol court. Others around him LAUGH at a joke we cannot HEAR. Then, re a painting behind him:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 53 Lost City of Z White 7/31/15 55.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES MURRAY
dialogues.text: I have painted these works. All of the home is my work--these sculptures as well... INT. FAWCETT LONDON HOME - FAWCETT’S OFFICE - DAY 53 It is FILLED with artifacts--from Amazonia, from Ceylon, other exotic locations: spears, Indian blankets, pottery, Incan attire. And the Buddha. The TICK-TOCK and GONG of a grandfather clock... Young JACK excitedly leafs through his father’s SCRAPBOOK wearing a piece of Amazonian Indian headgear. He is fascinated. Toddler Brian pulls out some Indian necklaces

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Percy enters:

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: Boys--these are not your toys. If you wish to play you may go outside. If you wish to remain, you must sit quietly. We PAN OVER TO REVEAL Nina entering the room. She moves t give Brian his milk. A beat, then:

dialogues.speaker: NINA FAWCETT
dialogues.text: You might think to donate much of this to the RGS. They can preserve it better than we can.

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: (looks at her; beat) I’m not going to do that.

dialogues.speaker: NINA FAWCETT
dialogues.text: (surprised, confused) Why not?

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: They believe I’m crazed, prone to hallucination. They value only the survey work. They do not respect my archeological discovery at all.

dialogues.speaker: NINA FAWCETT
dialogues.text: (re: pottery on the desk) Then I suggest you either ignore them or you prove your case, in public. You have those pieces as evidence. You can show them. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: +e HH OH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 54 Lost City of Z Pink Revision Set 8/24/15 56.

dialogues.speaker: NINA FAWCETT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And if we must, we shall find more evidence. (beat) Then we shall find more evidence. As they will noy yet allow a womamn through the doors of their august establishment, we will look elsewheere and prove your case in public. ANGLE ON FAWCETT. His FACE LIGHTENS.

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: If they only knew... you would be the true cause of their envy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is the dark and vast archives of the famed library. Fawcett is in the stacks, looking through materials. SUPERIMPOSE: “FEBRUARY 1909.” He takes out some FOLDERS, walks over to the big table wh Nina sits, her hands full of ancient paper. Fawcett sits down across from her, begins to look through the items in own folders.

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: Arrow drawings, meant to represent fractional distances, evidence of advanced mathematics. It’s incredible... (to Nina) I should have engaged the Indians more directly--they no doubt had a great deal to teach me. No response from Nina, who had been sifting through anoth set of old and frayed documents, letters, writings. She SEEMS TO HAVE STOPPED. Staring at one YELLOWED PIECE OF PAPER, for seconds on end. PERCY FAWCETT (CONT’D) Cheeky? (beat) Cheeky, did you hear me? Nina does not look over at Fawcett. She does not move, ju stares at that paper. At last, Nina looks at Fawcett.

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lost City of Z Pink Revision Set 8/24/15 56A.

dialogues.speaker: NINA FAWCETT
dialogues.text: I believe you have got your proof. At that moment, the CAMERA TILTS DOWN to REVEAL THE YELLO DOCUMENT. Then we HEAR:  55 Lost City of Z White 7/31/15 57.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The room is PACKED with dozens of scientists and explorer from across Europe. CIVILIANS line the BALCONIES. In the first level, we NOTICE that MEN sit with each other, and few WOMEN there are sit in a separate section, fanning themselves. PERCY FAWCETT is in front of the room, near JAMES MURRAY; NINA SHOWS UP, sits in the WOMEN’S SECTION. * HENRY COSTIN and ARTHUR MANLEY enter, all smiles, and go their seats. SIR JOHN SCOTT KELTIE, the secretary of the RGS, and SIR GEORGE GOLDIE are next to Fawcett, in great humor.

dialogues.speaker: SIR GEORGE GOLDIE
dialogues.text: Revel in this, my dear boy. You will relive it with your children until the end of your days. + eH

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: Yes, Sir George. I shall try.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keltie has stepped up to the podium and is banging on the hammer:

dialogues.speaker: SIR JOHN SCOTT KELTIE
dialogues.text: Gentlemen, good afternoon. HOOTS, HOLLERS, CHEERS. WILD APPLAUSE. (The MEETING IS LIKE A ROWDY BRITISH PARLIAMENT MEETING, interruptions and yelling par for the course.) SIR JOHN SCOTT KELTIE (CONT’D) * I should like to introduce one of our brothers, whose achievements are well-known here and not inconsiderable--the Honorable Mr. James Murray! ROUSING APPLAUSE. A BEAMING James Murray stands:

dialogues.speaker: JAMES MURRAY
dialogues.text: I met a remarkable man but a few * months ago upon his return from a place no one here has ever ventured. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lost City of Z White 7/31/15 58.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES MURRAY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Major Percy Fawcett has demonstrated--to me, at least--that there is a place where the explorer can go forth and exhibit perseverance, energy, courage, forethought, and all those qualities of an explorer of the times now passing away. Gentlemen, I give you...MAJOR PERCY FAWCETT! As Fawcett stands, amidst cheers, we overhear a whisper f William Barclay: * MURMURS. STANDING in the CROWD:

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM BARCLAY
dialogues.text: Now for fairy tales from the resident Buddhist!

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: My esteemed colleagues...it is now my firm belief that Amazonia is far more than the green desert many of us had supposed. I am proposing a that Amazonia contains a hidden civilization--one that may well predate our own. SKEPTICISM. The room is RESTLESS. Interrupting,

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM BARCLAY
dialogues.text: Major Fawcett, I am Mr. William Barclay, of Bedford. I have been in South America. + eH

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: Mr. Barclay.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM BARCLAY
dialogues.text: To be clear: are you insisting on mythical kingdoms of gold? Those * fantasies lured the Conquistadors to destruction--

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: SIR--it was the Conquistadors and WE who have been destroying Amazonia. This is a crime that must be stopped. I have seen with my own eyes evidence of their civilization and I assure you it is real--

dialogues.speaker: RANDOM SCIENTIST
dialogues.text: What is your point? *  Lost City of Z Yellow Revision Set 8/6/15 59.

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: Perhaps it is too difficult for some of you to admit. We, who have been steeped in the bigotry of the Church for so long, cannot give much credence to an “older civilization”--particularly one created by a race the white man has so brutally condemned to slavery and death. YET WE MUST ENGAGE WITH

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM BARCLAY
dialogues.text: Savages, in Westminster Abbey! LAUGHTER. Percy, shouting the first word:

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: HENCE your disrespect--but I ask you, what is at stake? If we may learn of a city where one was considered impossible to exist, it might well write a whole new chapter in human history. Man would be shown as a conqueror of his environment and not a slave to it! Outright BOOING now. Fawcett shouts over the boos: PERCY FAWCETT (CONT’D) CONSIDER MY EVIDENCE! My sightings of statues and archeological finds! Fawcett HOLDS UP A PIECE OF POTTERY: PERCY FAWCETT (CONT’D) Antiquities as sophisticated as any in Asia or Europe, in the middle of the jungle!

dialogues.speaker: RANDOM SCIENTIST
dialogues.text: Pots and pans, pots and pans! Many in the ROOM begin to chant, “POTS AND PANS!” Costin, who is finding all of this most amusing, leans forward, c his hands around his mouth and screams:

dialogues.speaker: HENRY COSTIN
dialogues.text: Shut your hole!  Lost City of Z Yellow Revision Set 8/6/15 59A. Then LAUGHS RIOTOUSLY at his own outburst. Fawcett continues, himself most amused at the riot he’s causing:

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: (yelling above the crowd) AND after my return from the jungle, I have examined a signal document dating from the Conquistadors. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lost City of Z White 7/31/15

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It states explicitly the discovery of a lost city in Amazonia! Uncovered earlier this week, a copy in the archives of Trinity College in Dublin. Its original from Rio De Janeiro, written by a Portugese soldier. "Historical account, large, hidden ancient city, 1753. We came upon ruins of an ancient city, bedecked with gold. Stone archways, roads, temple, ancient symbols.”

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM BARCLAY
dialogues.text: El Dorado!

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: No, gentlemen--I call it “Z"”--the ultimate piece of the human puzzle! It is there and we must find it! James Murray stands. Shouts, pointing:

dialogues.speaker: CHALLENGE
dialogues.text: Fawcett looks around the room. Which begins to explode. PERCY FAWCETT (CONT’D)

dialogues.speaker: THERE
dialogues.text: Costin stands, POINTING DIRECTLY AT FAWCETT:

dialogues.speaker: BUT--
dialogues.text: (smiles)

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: Mr. Manley! What say YOU?!?
+ eH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 56 Lost City of Z White 7/31/15 61. NINA stands, CLAPPING. ANGLE ON HENRY COSTIN and ARTHUR MANLEY, here too, as they stand on their feet, applauding JAMES MURRAY is basking, a KING here. Others JEER, howeve Slightly humbled, William Barclay SITS DOWN. Percy Fawcett remains standing at the podium, determined, even somewhat amused by the insanity he’s caused...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Percy and Nina, in bed. Dark. A beat. They are touching each other’s hands. It should have the mood of being post coital. It is raining outside. After a beat:

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: I have such high hopes, Cheeky... (beat) Mr. James Murray has added immeasurably to the luster of our mission. And...with his participation, I genuinely believe we may have acquired the keys to immortality. ANGLE ON NINA as she ponders mentioning something. And th

dialogues.speaker: NINA FAWCETT
dialogues.text: (readies herself) I...do believe I am quite ready to accompany you on your next journey as well. Fawcett is surprised and flummoxed:

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: What...?

dialogues.speaker: NINA FAWCETT
dialogues.text: The children will be off to school by the time it would begin. And I’ve learned to read the stars and navigate, and become very well- versed in the history of the region. (beat) After all, it was I who found the document.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lost City of Z White 7/31/15 62.

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: (dumbfounded; stuttering-- with a laugh) That would be--impossible. It’s not a place at all for a woman. She sits up:

dialogues.speaker: NINA FAWCETT
dialogues.text: Not a place? We believe firmly in the equality between us. So does he, now:

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: Equality, yes--of course. But in mind, not in body. The rigors of such a trip would be beyond your imagination. She turns away from him, turning onto the edge of the bed beat. Then, with her back to him:

dialogues.speaker: NINA FAWCETT
dialogues.text: I believe it is generally acknowledged that the pain a woman experiences in childbirth far exceeds anything a man must endure.

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: This is not about childbirth--

dialogues.speaker: NINA FAWCETT
dialogues.text: What do you know of childbirth? Have you witnessed a minute of it, much less endured it? He gets up, out of the bed, walks to face her. Kneeling:

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: Cheeky--the jungle is years of hard work and experience in the art of soldiering. It’s about maggots in your skin, and deadly snakes, and disease. I love you and I could not bear that. (beat) The children need their mother. She gets up, off the bed, walks to her dresser. He STANDS does not approach her (instead, staying close to the bed)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lost City of Z White 7/31/15 63.

dialogues.speaker: NINA FAWCETT
dialogues.text: Somehow I was able to bear the dangers you faced, the years you were gone. This way, we might be together--

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: You're my wife. I need you here, not as a tentmate in need of constant care. Be reasonable. She turns to him, flush with anger:

dialogues.speaker: NINA FAWCETT
dialogues.text: You will throw “reasonable” in my face?

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT, (SIMULTANEOUS)
dialogues.text: I'm simply speaking the truth-- She approaches him, strong and evincing a centeredness:

dialogues.speaker: NINA FAWCETT
dialogues.text: Was it reasonable to stay here and struggle to provide for the children while you wandered the jungle? Now you’ve no relationship with them whatsoever. And you have given no thought to my aspirations. He turns away from her, his hand slicing the air as he ma his points:

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: Men and women have each performed their roles since the beginnings of time. This is a cornerstone of our civilization. A man does not take his wife into the most dangerous place in the world on a whim!

dialogues.speaker: NINA FAWCETT
dialogues.text: I did expect more understanding from you and I am disgraced by your ignorant posture! Young JACK enters. He stares at the quarreling couple. He GRABS ONTO HIS MOTHER'S LEG with a FEROCIOUSNESS:

dialogues.speaker: NINA FAWCETT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m all right, darling. Your father and I were just having a discussion.  57 Lost City of Z White 7/31/15 64. Jack will not let go of his mother as he STARES at HIS

dialogues.speaker: NINA FAWCETT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (to Jack) It’s late, Jack. Return to your bed. I will come tuck you in ina moment. Jack won't budge.

dialogues.speaker: JACK FAWCETT
dialogues.text: Mother, I love you.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: The child finally lets go and leaves the room. She turns back to Percy. A LONG BEAT. Then she moves to him, takes his hand.

dialogues.speaker: NINA FAWCETT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’ve not prepared myself for the jungle, it is true... They come together. Softly, emotional:

dialogues.speaker: NINA FAWCETT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (emotional; sotto) I couldn't bear that you might think my dreams ridiculous...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SUPERIMPOSE: “MATO GROSSO REGION, BRAZIL. 1912”. The party hacks away. Fawcett, Costin, Manley, two Indian men, and James Murray, bringing up the rear. Two MULES, t HORSES, three DOGS. Fawcett leads and is ferocious, hacki as if he were swatting bees, with a giant machete in one and a map in the other. (Fawcett is looking slightly native.)

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: (calling out) One hundred twenty-one miles until Oviedo’s last marking! (to Costin) (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: +e HF

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lost City of Z Green Revision Set 09/30/2015 65. Costin has stopped, is examining himself.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY COSTIN
dialogues.text: Damn these things... Fawcett then looks down at Costin’s arm. He’s got MAGGOTS eating his flesh. And an INECTION which has begun in his nostrils--ESPUNDIA. FAWCETT PAUSES. HENRY COSTIN (CONT’D) My nose now, too. Don’t YOU ever get so much as a bee sting?

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: (still to Costin; jokes) Mr. Costin, do you not know I have not my equal for virtue in the service? The insects honor this! Fawcett is immediately on the move again, slides down a m path toward the RIVER. Way behind him: Murray is struggli The weight of the backpack. PERCY FAWCETT (CONT’D) Where’s Mr. Murray?

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR MANLEY
dialogues.text: Bringing up the rear, Chief. Calls out:

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: Mr. Murray!

dialogues.speaker: JAMES MURRAY
dialogues.text: Yes, Major Fawcett!

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: How are you managing?

dialogues.speaker: JAMES MURRAY
dialogues.text: (huffing and puffing) Very well, Major! Acquiring many samples! But--but my pack’s getting quite heavy! Perhaps...I ought to leave some of my accoutrements behind!

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: You don’t want to be ill-equipped for the journey ahead! You’1ll need all you can carry! +e * HF

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lost City of Z Green Revision Set 09/30/2015 65A.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES MURRAY
dialogues.text: Of course! I’m speaking merely of my extra clothes! They’re slowing me down a touch, that’s all! (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 58 Lost City of Z Goldenrod Revision Set 10/18/15 66.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES MURRAY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m sure to be moving better if I might lose them! Fawcett looks back at Murray, who is lagging way behind:

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: Very well--when we get to the river. But you MUST keep one change of clothes and your mattress!

dialogues.speaker: HENRY COSTIN
dialogues.text: Bugger probably wishes he were back on the South Pole... Fawcett stops. Turns around:

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: (almost peeved at Costin) Mr. Costin, he’s proven his valor beyond doubt when you and I were wet behind the ears. (beat) He’1l pull his weight soon enough.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY COSTIN
dialogues.text: And what weight. (sotto) He’1l wind up bringing us down with him, I tell you... Fawcett continues to chop away. The group reaches the riverbank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Group is in canoes. Quiet, except for Manley:

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR MANLEY
dialogues.text: We've gotten ahead of the others...

dialogues.speaker: JAMES MURRAY
dialogues.text: A magnificent view, Mr. Fawcett.

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 59 Lost City of Z Goldenrod Revision Set 10/18/15 67.

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You'll see greater sights than this, I promise you...

dialogues.speaker: JAMES MURRAY
dialogues.text: The thought thrills me, Major! I assure you, it thrills me! Murray then puts his handkerchief in the water.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY COSTIN
dialogues.text: I don’t advise that. We don’t know what’s in that water yet. Murray nods, stops what he is doing. Beat. ALL OF A SUDDEN: ARROWS! Arrows and spears rain down on t men.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES MURRAY
dialogues.text: Savages! Arm yourselves! MURRAY takes out his RIFLE. In fact, ALL the men--save Fawcett--take out their RIFLES and FIRE INTO THE AIR. Fawcett sees the Indians through the trees. Costin looks and down:

dialogues.speaker: HENRY COSTIN
dialogues.text: We’re surrounded! FAWCETT SPINS HIS HEAD AROUND. They seem DOOMED. The GUNS ARE FIRING, IN THE AIR. The ARROWS COME, FAST AND FURIOUS ANGLE ON FAWCETT as he seems to think of something... Fawcett yells to his comrades:

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: Hold your fire! HOLD YOUR FIRE! The canoes halt on the bank and the men get out, moving through the water to the:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MURRAY moves near the riverbank, hiding from the arrows u tree branches.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES MURRAY
dialogues.text: Look for cover, men! Fawcett instructs Arthur Manley to:  60 Lost City of Z Green Revision Set 09/30/2015 68.

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: Mr. Manley! Play your accordion!

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR MANLEY
dialogues.text: My accordion--?!?

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: “Soldiers of the Queen,” come on!

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR MANLEY
dialogues.text: All due respect sir, they seem likely to skin us alive!

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: Mr. Manley! Do as I say! (to everyone) Everyone--“Soldiers of the Queen”! A “YES, SIR,” could be heard. Manley begins to play, and whole party begins to sing:

dialogues.speaker: THE ENTIRE PARTY
dialogues.text: In the fight for England's glory, lads, of its worldwide glory let us sing! Fawcett then unties the handkerchief around his neck and waves it above his head at the Indians. No effect.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fawcett enters the water again. Waving his handkerchief. The river gets deeper. He stops somewhere near the middle with the river around his armpits. THE ARROWS AND SPEARS NOT STOP COMING. He wades directly INTO the fusillade of arrows. He repeat over and over, in Portuguese and other dialects:

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT, (SUBTITLE)
dialogues.text: Friend! Friend! Friend! The arrows keep coming, FASTER THAN EVER. Several come INCREDIBLY CLOSE, zooming right by his head. We can even hear a ZIPPING SOUND. But Fawcett braves it nonetheless, holding a SURVEYING BOOK in front of his face to protect from the arrows. THWACK! An ARROW HITS the SURVEYING BOOK in front of his face! Fawcett stands there, a man between two sides of the rive between two worlds maybe, and closes his eyes.  Aél1 B6él 61 62 Lost City of Z Green Revision Set 09/30/2015 69. The water surrounds Fawcett’s armpits; no one moves.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: EXT. CEYLON BEACH Aél1 A FLASH of shots, over which we STILL HEAR the sounds fro the jungle: 1. A SHOT OF THE BUDDHA - a statue, surrounded by dark vi a COLORED RIBBON is TIED to it, BLOWING IN THE WIND 2. A SHOT OF NINA and PERCY - on the BEACH. Holding hands 3. A SHOT OF A BUDDHIST PRIEST - standing in front of the

dialogues.speaker: A WHISPERED VOICE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I will take the Pansil... I vow not to kill or injure any living thing...nor to take that which is not given...

dialogues.speaker: CUT BACK TO
dialogues.text: EXT. RIVER B6él Then: THE ARROWS AND SPEARS STOP. Fawcett opens his eyes. The sound returns--except that it’s gone quiet. A GUARAYO INDIAN peers out from the forest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paddling out toward Fawcett in a raft, the GUARAYO takes handkerchief from Fawcett; Fawcett motions to be taken across, and the two go to the Indian side with Fawcett kneeling humbly on the flimsy float. The whole group waits in silence for Fawcett, who disappe into the forest.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES MURRAY
dialogues.text: (to the others, loud) All of you! Should the red man attack, keep your eye on me! Rally to me at all costs! EXT. RIVERBANK —- MOMENTS LATER 62 MOMENTS LATER: the Indian emerges, CHEERFULLY wearing Fawcett’s Stetson hat. PANIC! IS FAWCETT DEAD?!? THEN: +e HH OH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 63 Lost City of Z Green Revision Set 09/30/2015 69A. Fawcett emerges too, smiling. He waves to his men.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES MURRAY
dialogues.text: (to himself) Good God. The group, including Murray, all venture across the river

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The men slowly approach the area. Human skulls abound. A HUMAN BEING’S BODY is BEING COOKED on a SPIT. The troops spooked. Murray, in particular, seems appalled.

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: I recognize a bit of the chief's language. It’s safe for us.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES MURRAY
dialogues.text: Are you mad?!? They’re cannibals!

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: I recognize your reluctance and I sympathize. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 64 Lost City of Z Green Revision Set 09/30/2015 70.

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But I’m asking you to trust my experience--we must attempt to engage.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES MURRAY
dialogues.text: (incredulous) They've cooked a body, for chrissakes! Have you gone insane?

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: It’s a dead member of the tribe-- his spirit will enter them if they eat it. It’s their custom. (to the whole group) They may have critical information about our destination.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES MURRAY
dialogues.text: (to the others) They’1l kill us, these savages! (to himself) I refuse this madness. I refuse it! Manley, Costin, and the others look at Fawcett as though is insane as well. MURRAY STARTS TO BACK AWAY, toward the FOREST. JAMES MURRAY (CONT’D) Madness! Fawcett sees the others agree with Murray to a degree. He doesn’t respond, and a brief look of madness, of possessi flashes across his face. So instead he walks to:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The other men eventually, reluctantly follow Fawcett into tent--though conspicuously missing is MURRAY. Packed with both our guys and the Guarayos now. A beat of silence, th to Costin:

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: Can you give them something?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY COSTIN
dialogues.text: Yes--yes, of course. Costin stupidly strikes _a_match, and though panicked, th Indians calm quickly when Fawcett takes out a glittering necklace:  Lost City of Z Green Revision Set 09/30/2015 70A.

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT, (SUBTITLE)
dialogues.text: No--it’s a gift! A gift! For you. And your--your son?  Lost City of Z White 7/31/15 71. The Chief Guarayo, sitting next to a boy, gestures to him PERCY FAWCETT (SUBTITLE) (CONT’D) Yes, wonderful... I have sons, too. The Chief smiles, points to Costin, Manley. Fawcett laugh PERCY FAWCETT (CONT’D) (CONT’D) No no, my sons are far away.

dialogues.speaker: CHIEF GUARAYO, (SUBTITLE)
dialogues.text: How can you be so far from them?

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: (his smile disappears) Our world is not like yours... ANOTHER GUARAYO, A WOMAN, responds:

dialogues.speaker: GUARAYO WOMAN, (SUBTITLE)
dialogues.text: All people are made of the same clay. The Chief takes a crushed BERRY COMPOUND and gestures to FAWCETT around his EYES. FAWCETT COMPLIES, spreading the DARK RED MIXTURE ON HIS FACE. Then one of the GUARAYOS reaches for Costin’s ARM. At fir Costin has trepidation, then allows the man to grab his forearm. THE GUARAYO WHISTLES LOUDLY, in a STRANGE PITCH. And the MAGGOTS in Costin’s arm STAND UP. The Guarayo simply squeezes gently and the maggots fall on the ground. Costi arm_is cured of the maggots--! Costin TRIES TO WHISTLE like the GUARAYO but cannot:

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: Not sure we have the touch. (back to the Guarayo;

dialogues.speaker: SUBTITLE
dialogues.text: We're looking for old houses, many houses, many many people, deep into the forest. Do you know of this? The Guarayo speaks in his native tongue. Then, to Costin: PERCY FAWCETT (CONT’D) He’s heard rumors, but is uncertain. Further down the river, he believes there’1l be others who can help us.  65 66 Lost City of Z Green Revision Set 09/30/2015 72. Then another Guarayo motions to his mouth. Food. PERCY FAWCETT (SUBTITLE) (CONT’D) Food--yes--thank you! ANGLE ON THE CHIEF as we GO TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Guarayo crushes a plant with a stone and lets the juice spill into the water. A milky cloud forms. After a moment DOZENS OF FISH RISE TO THE SURFACE, gasping. A Guarayo bo wades into the water and pulls out the biggest. Fawcett, had been making his own face up with beads, bows his head thanks as he takes the fish. Fawcett turns and looks at the water.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY COSTIN
dialogues.text: MY GOD! It’s only stunned them! They don’t kill any more than they have to! ‘S remarkable! The other fish that the boy didn’t withdraw from the wate swim away. EXT. GUARAYOS TENT —- CLEARING 66 A thunderstorm is coming. Fawcett, with his makeup lookin native now, walks into the clearing, and in front of him sees that here are THOUSANDS of Indians living about. An astonishing discovery. And they are not just savages. The have advanced methods of farming; MAIZE GROWS AS FAR AS T EYE CAN SEE. Costin approaches:

dialogues.speaker: HENRY COSTIN
dialogues.text: We seem to have lost Mr. Murray.

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: They've made the jungle into farmland somehow. All the families are working together--and there is no rank or superiority among them. It’s truly humbling.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY COSTIN
dialogues.text: Chief--

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: Designed at right angles, mathematical in its precision. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 67 Lost City of Z Green Revision Set 09/30/2015 73.

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It confirms so much of what we believed. (to Costin) Can you imagine what our lost city must be like...?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY COSTIN
dialogues.text: Chief, did you hear me about Mr. Murray? Your great polar explorer’s gone lost in the trees--

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: Mr. Murray is an accomplished man-- we're not to fret over him. And anyhow, he can’t have gone very far. Tell the men I’ve designed new rafts--the canoes are riddled with arrows and useless now. We’1ll be off on foot in the morning... Fawcett walks into the field of MAIZE. The wind blows the plants, and Fawcett is an incongruous figure amidst the Guarayos, who tend to the crops. Costin watches as Fawcett approaches the LEADER OF THE GUARAYOS and teaches him to HANDSHAKE. A GOODBYE OF SORTS

dialogues.speaker: CHIEF GUARAYO, (SUBTITLE)
dialogues.text: You may stay here with us. Join your spirit to ours.

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT, (SUBTITLE)
dialogues.text: (a beat; awe) You honor me beyond words. But it is not yet time for me to rest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Murray is asleep on the ground. He has gotten lost. Strew nearby: his machete, all the photos of his family. Sittin in the mud. Food eaten, the wrappings all over. Turkish cigarette butts... He awakens to see FAWCETT AND THE REST OF THE GROUP, approaching him. Fawcett sees all the food’s been eaten. Murray, Fawcett must appear a strange figure--with his FA PAINT, now slightly streaked from the rain like tears...

dialogues.speaker: JAMES MURRAY
dialogues.text: Thank God you’ve found me--I--I got lost. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lost City of Z Green Revision Set 09/30/2015 74.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES MURRAY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I didn’t think we’d survive in the presence of those horrible savages. My clothes and mouth--full of grit!

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: You'll be looked after. We must be on our way now-- BUT THEN: Fawcett reaches down, finds: AN EMPTY BOX OF CARAMELS. INSIDE THE LID: “For your journey, darling, I l you. Nina”. A FAWCETT FAMILY PHOTO IS INCLUDED. Something changes in Fawcett. DARKENS. PERCY FAWCETT (CONT’D) This...was from my wife and children... (beat) For all of us.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES MURRAY
dialogues.text: Yes--I know--I was hungry! It was supposed to be just a short rest. The scrub’s incredibly dense and I fell. I think I’ve a terrible fever... A BEAT. And then Fawcett looks like he is about to EXPLOD His EYES BULGE WITH RAGE:

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: Get up. Fawcett turns, ferociously hacks a branch with a machete.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES MURRAY
dialogues.text: Mr. Fawcett--just one more moment of rest... I’m very tired-- Fawcett FREEZES. SPINS BACK AROUND. Raging:

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: You're tired? You have no right to be tired! (beat) My own sons--at their tender ages-- could be counted on more than you. I could be with them at this very moment, yet I am here with YOU, to attempt great things.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He collects himself, bends down again. Privately:  68 Lost City of Z Green Revision Set 09/30/2015 75. PERCY FAWCETT (CONT’D) You stole from the group and violated our trust. I won't have this again.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES MURRAY
dialogues.text: (shocked) How dare you speak to me that way! Have you seen my leg? HAVE YOU?!? Fawcett looks down: Murray’s leg has a gash. Fawcett bend down, looks at the wound. The other men surround Murray. Murray's things have scattered all over the jungle.

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: It’s not yet infected, but if blood * poisoning should set in, you'll be a dead man. (beat) If you’d stayed with the group and trusted the so-called savage, you’d be fed--and cured. As it is, we’ve got to hope for the best.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES MURRAY
dialogues.text: (at a loss for words) Yes, well, I’1l, I’11l do that! ANGLE ON MURRAY as FAWCETT walks away. He is STEAMING.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are rafting. Dizzying. Murray is SHIVERING, VERY SIC a mess. Maggots have overwhelmed his legs. Fawcett and

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Costin are maneuvering the raft. * BUMP! The rafts shift with the river’s flow. Murray and * Costin fall off the raft. Costin knows what to do; he sta swimming to shore. Murray does not. *

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: Swim to shore! The water’s too * rough for piranhas! * Instead, Murray attempts to hold onto the raft and threat to capsize it. PERCY FAWCETT (CONT’D) I said, swim to shore! The raft starts to shift. Fawcett is enraged:  Lost City of Z Green Revision Set 09/30/2015 75A. PERCY FAWCETT (CONT’D) God damn it! (beat) (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 69 Lost City of Z Green Revision Set 09/30/2015 76. PERCY FAWCETT (CONT’D) Let go! You pink-eyed weakling--

dialogues.speaker: LET GO
dialogues.text: The raft tips, and TWO CRATES OF SUPPLIES GO TUMBLING * OVERBOARD. Manley tries to stop them, to no avail... *

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fawcett directs the raft to the shore using a bamboo pole The raft bumps up against the riverbank. Everyone has congregated. All are out of breath. Fawcett eyes Murray with utter contempt.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR MANLEY
dialogues.text: We've just lost a third of our * rations! *

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: (glaring at Murray) * Getting to the city and back was already going to be difficult.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES MURRAY
dialogues.text: For heaven's sake, I was drowning! Didn't you SEE?!?

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: There was no chance of that! And this after you took our food!

dialogues.speaker: JAMES MURRAY
dialogues.text: I suppose the honorable course of action would be for me to starve, then? Is that it? Is that what you wish for? My death?!? Fawcett, to Costin:

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: Where are we now, do we know? Are we behind our schedule?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY COSTIN
dialogues.text: Yes. We are-- *

dialogues.speaker: JAMES MURRAY
dialogues.text: You're entirely without mercy! You could at least slow down to give a lame man a chance for his life! Still not paying attention to Murray, Fawcett remains fix on Costin. Seeing a couple of ABANDONED HUTS behind Costi  Lost City of Z Green Revision Set 09/30/2015 76A.

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: Pitch camp here for the night, we'll determine our progress.  70 Lost City of Z Green Revision Set 09/30/2015 77.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES MURRAY
dialogues.text: And now you ignore me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One of the HORSES starts to collapse. Looks very ill. A CREWMEMBER turns to the others, shouting:

dialogues.speaker: CREWMEMBER
dialogues.text: Horse down! The Crewmember takes out his gun, SHOOTS THE HORSE.

dialogues.speaker: ACROSS THE FIRE
dialogues.text: Murray has a fever. Truly sick: swollen, distended, in terrible shape--covered with maggots. A colorful snake ha from a tree over his head. He moans over and over, shivering. To a noncomprehending Indian, he gets deliriou

dialogues.speaker: JAMES MURRAY
dialogues.text: I’m going to die too, just like that horse. I’m a man of property...now worth as much as that horse... SEEING THE MAGGOTS, TEARS COME TO MURRAY’S EYES. COMPLETE

dialogues.speaker: SICK, DYING, DELIRIOUS
dialogues.text: JAMES MURRAY (CONT’D) The affrontery of this upstart, and his vulgar quest for glory... Like a Judas...delivering me over to this jungle when he handed over our Lord, to be crucified... Father, forgive me this trespasses, As we forgive them that trespass against us... But...but let me not compare myself to thee, my Lord. You have delivered me from other evils, Lord. The fierce cold in Antarctica, was I weak then? (strained smile through tears) He is not even worthy to kiss the hem of my garment, Lord. Even as I am not worthy to touch yours... Give me strength to survive, to forgive this man his sins against me...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lost City of Z Green Revision Set 09/30/2015 78. Costin comes over to Fawcett, who is standing near the fi Pondering...something. Manley is here, too.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY COSTIN
dialogues.text: We're about two weeks behind our planned pace. That’s my best guess, from the sextant and the * charts. * In the background, James Murray lets out a MOAN.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR MANLEY
dialogues.text: It appears our Mr. Murray’s got blood poisoning now.

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: Yes... I’d noticed that. (beat) So much for his good bloodline.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY COSTIN
dialogues.text: I caught him with our maize yesterday morning. He claimed it was from his own private store. + eH Fawcett moves closer. Sotto voce, looking at Murray:

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: I fooled myself for some time, but no longer--the man is a cancer. If * we keep him with us we won’t survive, much less reach the city and return to our families.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY COSTIN
dialogues.text: I say we ditch him, leave him to rot. I’ve wanted to from the beginning. His Lordship’s a coward and a thief. *

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR MANLEY
dialogues.text: I’m in agreement, Major--there aren’t two sets of rules, one for the high and one for the low.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY COSTIN
dialogues.text: What’s it going to be, Chief? * Fawcett eyes Murray.  Lost City of Z Green Revision Set 09/30/2015 78A.

dialogues.speaker: MOMENTS LATER
dialogues.text: PERCY APPROACHES MURRAY, around whom flies swarm. Murray eyes Fawcett suspiciously:

dialogues.speaker: JAMES MURRAY
dialogues.text: What is it...?  Lost City of Z Green Revision Set 09/30/2015 79. Fawcett speaks deliberately, almost as if proving a case courtroom. In measured and careful tones, like a speech h has prepared:

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: When traveling in the jungle without other resources, every man must realize that if he falls sick and cannot move with the others that there must be consequences. The others cannot wait and die with him. (beat) Do you understand? Murray seems to get it. An awkward beat, then: Murray sta to grip his revolver.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES MURRAY
dialogues.text: You’re only here--all of you-- because of the funds I provided! Costin whips his shotgun out, points it directly at Murra Pushes the shotgun up against his cheek. A tense moment.

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: Many of us have families back home. And I cannot allow you to further jeopardize the welfare of our entire party. (to Costin) Mr. Costin. As Costin takes Murray’s revolver from him:

dialogues.speaker: JAMES MURRAY
dialogues.text: You don’t care one whit about me or the rest of our party, Mr. Fawcett. You don’t even care about returning home--you only care about finding your bloody city!

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: There are some in our group that would have me abandon you here and leave you to die. But I will not. There are mining encampments south of us, along the river. In the morning you'll be on your way to them. I’11 give you our last horse with what supplies we can spare and an Indian to guide you.  71 72 Lost City of Z Green Revision Set 09/30/2015 80.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES MURRAY
dialogues.text: You'll pack me off with a bloody swamp wog, will you? (beat ) This calm willingness to abandon me is a queer thing to hear from an Englishman. But it does not surprise me, as I have now sufficiently gauged your class and character.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Murray is placed atop a mule. Manley and Costin have trai their guns on him. Fawcett notices MURRAY’S INFECTED KNEE

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: Godspeed, Mr. Murray--

dialogues.speaker: JAMES MURRAY
dialogues.text: (interrupting, with rage) Let’s hope our paths don’t ever cross again, Mr. Fawcett. For your sake. With that, Murray rides off. Fawcett and the others watch the mule disappears into the jungle.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY COSTIN
dialogues.text: Good riddance, I say.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR MANLEY
dialogues.text: Any chance for him, Chief?

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: Slim, to be sure. But it’s the best we could do... (beat) Let us go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fawcett leads the men as they slide down a steep canyon. RAIN comes. LIGHTNING. THE RUMBLE OF THUNDER. Fawcett looks up, through heavy downpour: SEES what he th is a MASSIVE STONE FACE CARVED INTO THE WALL OF THE CANYO A _GODLIKE VISION.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lost City of Z Green Revision Set 09/30/2015 81. Then, A ROAR. The “STONE FACE” CARVED INTO THE WALL OF TH CANYON seems to CRUMBLE AMIDST THE DOWNPOUR... Fawcett SEEMS in a TRANCE when--

dialogues.speaker: HENRY COSTIN
dialogues.text: Chief!

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: Yes, I saw it! We’re close now! The men are SOAKED. FROZEN. PANTING. FAWCETT, HOWEVER, IS

dialogues.speaker: HENRY COSTIN
dialogues.text: All our reserves are lost! The CAMERA TILTS DOWN. Costin and the others have flung o the rations CRATES. INSIDE, the rations are COVERED with OIL. Ruined: HENRY COSTIN (CONT’D) They're covered in paraffin! The bloody bastard destroyed them! (beat) We've got to head back!

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: We can’t! We’ve nothing to show for our efforts--no evidence--

dialogues.speaker: HENRY COSTIN
dialogues.text: MAJOR! With what little we’ve got on our backs, death would be certain within days! If we’d still had the horse you gave Murray and all it could carry, we might have a fighting chance! Fawcett ponders. Through gritted teeth and deep rage:

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: God damn me for a fool to bring him!  73 Lost City of Z Blue Revision Set 8/19/15 82. Then: he bashes the side of a rock repeatedly with his machete. Pure frustration over the whole situation. Over this, we HEAR:

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: To be sent to the R.G.S.: Mr. James Murray was forced to separate from our expedition to seek medical attention. His location is currently unknown, and he has most likely perished.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fawcett has arrived in La Paz, Bolivia, to the British Embassy. He is writing on a notepad a message to the RGS, which an English Officer is typing:

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: The British Minister has his case in hand and his family should not be contacted unless there is definitive news of some kind. The rest of the group shall arrive back in England as soon as is possible... Fawcett looks at the counter. CLOSE SHOT ON a newspaper. The headline, in Spanish, is all about the ASSASSINATION THE ARCHDUKE FERDINAND and WAR IN EUROPE. The ENGLISH OFFICER sees Percy looking at the paper. In a jolly tone:

dialogues.speaker: ENGLISH OFFICER
dialogues.text: (grinning) Looks like a war with Fritz! We'd better all get home or we’ll miss our chance to fight!

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: (eyes him; then, re telegram) Please send this immediately.

dialogues.speaker: ENGLISH OFFICER
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. WE SEE PERCY WALK OUT OF THE OUTLET into the distance...  75 Lost City of Z White 7/31/15 83.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It’s quiet, punctuated only by the sounds of boys playing the distance: Fawcett’s sons play with a rugby ball. * CLOSE SHOT on a BEAUTIFUL BABY GIRL, ALMOST A TODDLER, sitting on the ground surrounded by blocks. We HEAR:

dialogues.speaker: NINA FAWCETT, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: That is Joan, as you might have guessed. Widen to SEE FAWCETT and NINA in the backyard of the hous eyeing their daughter. Nina has a BROAD SMILE.

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: Beautiful name. For a beautiful child. (to the toddler) Joan, I’m your father. * SHE SMILES AT HIM, POKES HIS FACE. An instant connection.

dialogues.speaker: NINA FAWCETT
dialogues.text: I’ll go and get the boys--they’re * playing a fierce match--

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: No no. Let them finish. It’s good * for them... *

dialogues.speaker: NINA FAWCETT
dialogues.text: (beat) * There are many urgent telegrams waiting for you, inside. Fawcett nods.

dialogues.speaker: NINA FAWCETT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Perhaps it’s about the war, on the continent--

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: (interrupting her) It’s not. It’s about my mission. I’1l need to go to London soon, no doubt. There will be a reckoning. * He steps forward, watches his boys play in the distance. PERCY FAWCETT (CONT’D) I came close, Cheeky. I had to turn back, for the good of the men. (fighting tears) (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 76 77 78 Lost City of Z White 7/31/15 84. PERCY FAWCETT (CONT’D) I face humiliation now... I did everything I could and I accomplished nothing. Her face contorts: ANGRY, she stands over him but remains outwardly calm:

dialogues.speaker: NINA FAWCETT
dialogues.text: If you have accomplished nothing, then what does that say about us? That all our efforts on behalf of this family have been for naught? Our willingness to live in something less than splendor will not be in vain. Fawcett turns back to face Nina; starts to walk to the ho

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: When the boys are done with their game, send them in and I’1l tell them what’s happened. Fawcett walks into the house. Looking around, he disappea but we still see his SHADOW. He buries his head in his hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A magnificent structure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fawcett walks down the hall and, looking lost, he enters:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An elegant space. FAWCETT EYES THE ROOM. Packed, with Sir George Goldie, Sir John Scott Keltie, and the rest of the gang we know--including Manley and Costin and William Bar among the roughly twenty in attendance.

dialogues.speaker: SIR JOHN SCOTT KELTIE
dialogues.text: Major. You know many of us here. Then a seated man with his back to us turns: JAMES MURRAY. Fawcett spots him, then moves to a seat; a trial-like atmosphere in the room, tense. A silent beat, then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: + eH  Lost City of Z Green Revision Set 09/30/2015 85. SIR JOHN SCOTT KELTIE (CONT’D) Mr. James Murray has arrived in London just this morning. Fawcett eyes Murray without a HINT of what has gone on between them. If anything, he seems calm, with the trace a smile on his face:

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: I would like to congratulate you. On your safe return. (beat) A remarkable effort. No answer by Murray.

dialogues.speaker: SIR JOHN SCOTT KELTIE
dialogues.text: Mr. Murray contends that you abandoned him. (beat) Is this true?

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: No, it is not. He was sent back with both food and money. It was a necessary maneuver, in order to save lives.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES MURRAY
dialogues.text: He also tried to kill me, Sir George. Ask him about THAT--

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: That’s absurd. We almost killed ourselves giving you what rations we could!

dialogues.speaker: JAMES MURRAY
dialogues.text: Sir John, we spent all our time playing around in the mud with savages. And may I say, I never saw any evidence of a lost city, either.

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: Mr. Murray, you were the reason we did not reach our destination!

dialogues.speaker: HENRY COSTIN
dialogues.text: (to Percy) Tell them--our rations were covered with paraffin!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lost City of Z Yellow Revision Set 8/6/15 85A.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES MURRAY
dialogues.text: I reject that accusation--  Lost City of Z Green Revision Set 09/30/2015 86.

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: (to the room) You may ask Mr. Manley here--or ANY * of the other members of my team--if * you have doubt of it. * SIR GEORGE GOLDIE, who has been listening this whole time STARES AT PERCY. Looks almost DISAPPOINTED in him.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES MURRAY
dialogues.text: Sir John, I will not tolerate any further insult from this young man! I have retained counsel and will proceed accordingly. And as for his lackeys--they’re swine, as untrustworthy as their master!

dialogues.speaker: HENRY COSTIN
dialogues.text: (to Percy) * It is out of respect for you that I * do not beat him like the dog he is. * Costin STANDS. Goldie speaks up, looking utterly heartbroken, near tears:

dialogues.speaker: SIR GEORGE GOLDIE
dialogues.text: Please. Sit down. * (Costin does so; then) * Gentlemen, our nation is now at * war, and it ill becomes us to hold onto private conflicts. I earnestly beseech you to come to an understanding. A beat. Then:

dialogues.speaker: JAMES MURRAY
dialogues.text: Well... I will...very generously offer that if Mr. Fawcett were * willing to apologize--here, in the company of the entire society, then...I might be inclined to drop my claims against him and the RGS. (beat) With certain conditions, of course.

dialogues.speaker: SIR JOHN SCOTT KELTIE
dialogues.text: What about it, Percy? Will you apologize?

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: For the general good, I am willing to reconcile. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lost City of Z Yellow Revision Set 8/6/15 86A.

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: However, I should like to hear Mr. Murray's conditions.  Lost City of Z White 7/31/15 87.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES MURRAY
dialogues.text: On the night I agreed to join you-- and allowed your star to enter my sphere--your wife was there to witness your ascent. My condition-- my sole condition--is that she once again be present. On this occasion she will witness your acknowledgement of the wrongs you have done me. Fawcett stews, contemplating a response in front of the enormous--and uncharacteristically quiet--group. Then:

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: When I last saw you, Mr. Murray, I was putting you on our only remaining horse and giving you more than your share of our food. The rest of my men urged me to leave you where you lay, but I could not bring myself to do so. And asa consequence I saved your life.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES MURRAY
dialogues.text: Saved my life, did you?!? You left me to die! Yet by my own expertise, which you despise, I was able to escape the hell to which you had abandoned me! And I now confound your hopes to bury your shame in that filthy jungle! (to Keltie) Mr. Secretary--I demand that apology!

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: Yes. I should apologize. (looks to Costin, Manley) To my crew. I’m sorry that I ever believed Mr. Murray to be worthy of your company. And that I ever mistook a man’s rank for his mettle. I shall not make that mistake again. Fawcett stands, walks toward the door. PERCY FAWCETT (CONT’D) Sir John, what your purpose can be in this ambush I cannot say. But you need fear no more embarrassment from me. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: + eH  79 80 Lost City of Z White 7/31/15 88. PERCY FAWCETT (CONT’D) I hereby resign myself from this institution. And I shall proceed on my own. Good day. MURRAY SMILES JUST A BIT as he says:

dialogues.speaker: JAMES MURRAY
dialogues.text: Mr. Fawcett, no man is an island unto himself--a fact you shall soon discover to your deep regret! I shall teach you what it means to challenge your betters!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fawcett gets out of a Hanson Cab.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fawcett enters. Nina’s been in the kitchen, extinguishing the oil lamps. She looks toward the door, looking grave. She and Percy exchange looks. Something is amiss:

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: What’s going on? (beat) WHAT’S WRONG?

dialogues.speaker: NINA FAWCETT
dialogues.text: You've received a letter. All former officers not currently posted must send their names to the War Office. (beat) I suppose it’s best we try and find your uniform. She goes back to extinguishing the lamps.

dialogues.speaker: NINA FAWCETT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (upset, trying not to be) Let us hope it’s a brief conflict.

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: Don’t be concerned, Cheeky. I’ve spent a whole life training for this. Besides, the jungle has never harmed me--a little war cannot beat that challenge. He walks up the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 81 Lost City of Z Pink Revision Set 8/24/15 89.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fawcett comes up the stairs, sees BRIAN AND JACK, at thei desks from the hall. Presumably doing homework. Jack is n almost a young teen now and Brian a boy. Fawcett stands n the doorway, looking at them. SMILES. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: JACK FAWCETT
dialogues.text: Father.

dialogues.speaker: BRIAN FAWCETT
dialogues.text: Papa.

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: Jack. Brian.

dialogues.speaker: BRIAN FAWCETT
dialogues.text: Papa, why are we at war?

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: (nonplussed) As to that, greater men than we must answer that question.

dialogues.speaker: JACK FAWCETT
dialogues.text: You're not going away again, are you? To fight?

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: If the reports are true, I must.

dialogues.speaker: JACK FAWCETT
dialogues.text: But you’ve only just returned.

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: I've received my orders, Jack. I’m obligated to serve.

dialogues.speaker: JACK FAWCETT
dialogues.text: What about your obligations to mother and to us? (beat) We are your family and you have abandoned us for many years.

dialogues.speaker: NINA FAWCETT
dialogues.text: Jack!  Lost City of Z Pink Revision Set 8/24/15 89A.

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: (shocked; darkens) How dare you talk to me in such a manner?  Lost City of Z Pink Revision Set 8/24/15 90.

dialogues.speaker: JACK FAWCETT
dialogues.text: How dare you, Father? You do not think of us. You think of Indians or Germans, or any other path to glory that you can find.

dialogues.speaker: NINA FAWCETT
dialogues.text: (appalled) JACK! You must stop it at ONCE!

dialogues.speaker: JACK FAWCETT
dialogues.text: Mother, I will NOT STOP! He’s returned a failure. ALL the papers are full of it! And now he wants to abandon us again! It is contemptible! Percy EXPLODES. He LUNGES ACROSS THE ROOM and SLAPS THE B with tremendous and frightening ferocity.

dialogues.speaker: BRIAN FAWCETT
dialogues.text: (bursting into tears) Father! Brian COVERS HIS EYES, deeply distraught. Nina steps forw to defend Percy, who, though furious, steps back--eyes * widened, still in a dazed fit of anger. *

dialogues.speaker: NINA FAWCETT
dialogues.text: Everything your father has done, * since the day you came into this world, has been to better your life, and that of your brother and sister. For your own sake, I hope * the day will come when you regret the things you have said to him. * Jack's FACE is buried in his pillow:

dialogues.speaker: JACK FAWCETT
dialogues.text: I hate him, Mother! I hope he * never comes back! * Percy exits the room. We PAN off this image to the WALL o the bedroom. A LARGE SPEAR from AMAZONIA--

dialogues.speaker: MATCH CUT TO
dialogues.text: 82 83 84 Lost City of Z Green Revision Set 09/30/2015 91.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A MACHINE GUN on a battle-scarred scene. Total devastatio We PAN past a field scorched by destruction, as far as th eye can see. No vegetation at all. The area is EERILY QUIET, only occasionally punctuated by a RAT-A-TAT-TAT or distant explosion. We SEE a TRENCH LINE. SUPERIMPOSE: “THE FRONT, RIVER SOMME, FRANCE. TWO YEARS LATER”.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The trench itself is filled with weary and shattered troo and rotting corpses. Blood and fumes. Urine and shit and bones and lice and maggots and rats. A dead man has drown in the slime, only part of his head exposed. HELL ON EART INT. BUNKER - FAWCETT’S SPACE 84 A table, a phone, a lantern, not much else. Dark corners. There’s someone in the corner, in that darkness. Manley i here, in uniform. He is reading a letter with a NEWSPAPER CLIPPING. He LAUGHS.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR MANLEY
dialogues.text: (amazed) Well what do you know! It appears our old friend Mr. James Murray isn’t so powerful after all! PERCY FAWCETT’S VOICE What’s that, Mr. Manley?

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR MANLEY
dialogues.text: He and his bloody cronies may have put us in this hellhole, but his latest expedition seems to have come a cropper. PERCY FAWCETT’S VOICE Please give me the details. Manley approaches the dark corner, holding the CLIPPING a putting it in Fawcett’s face (presumably). As he does so:

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR MANLEY
dialogues.text: Bastard went off on an arctic expedition with Canadians and mutinied--he’s not been heard from since!  85 86 Lost City of Z Green Revision Set 09/30/2015 92. ANGLE ON THE DARKNESS. We SEE an ARM REACH UP, out of the dark, and turn up the LANTERN. The LIGHT REVEALS only PAR OF FAWCETT’S SHOULDER, SURROUNDED BY LARGE DRAWINGS OF TH AMAZONIAN JUNGLE, FAMILY PHOTOS, ETC. An elaborate shrine MANLEY IS LAUGHING. Fawcett enters the light, and it looks like he’s aged a

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: Someone should warn the eskimos that Mr. Murray is on the prowl... THEY LAUGH.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A young man RUNS from atop the trench, JUMPING DOWN into trench. He runs toward the small bunker and ENTERS: INT. BUNKER - FAWCETT’S SPACE 86 Where Fawcett is in the midst of writing at his desk and Manley is reading. The TRENCH RUNNER announces himself:

dialogues.speaker: TRENCH RUNNER
dialogues.text: Sir! A message, from Colonel Howard! Fawcett READS THE NOTE. A beat. Then:

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: Thank you, Private. The Private salutes. Leaves. Percy looks unsettled.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR MANLEY
dialogues.text: What is it, Chief?

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: (very grave) There’s movement in the German position. Perhaps preparing for some kind of attack. (with disgust) We may be asked to withdraw...  87 88 Lost City of Z White 7/31/15 93.

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (sotto) Fools... He gets up, looks through the periscope to SEE: MOVEMENT AMONG THE GERMAN TROOPS. THEY ARE PREPARING THEIR GUNS. PERCY FAWCETT (CONT’D) How many men are at our command at present?

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR MANLEY
dialogues.text: Seven hundred, sir. And the two Indian brigades on horseback.

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: Gather up as many men as you can. Cooks and signallers as well. We'll go over the top at dawn.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR MANLEY
dialogues.text: Chief, if plans are being made to withdraw--

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: Those plans are absurd. We might all die if the Germans attack. Is that what you prefer? There is no other course open to us but to fight it out. (beat) There can be no retirement--our backs are against the wall. Prepare to go over the top. Any man who has not written to his loved ones should do so.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR MANLEY
dialogues.text: (humbled) Yes, Chief. Manley turns away, to carry out the orders.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fires illuminate the space. Fawcett checks his watch, the walks through the trench, passing frightened soldiers. Th toward the bunker, where he hears a CHEERFUL COMMOTION.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HE ENTERS THE BUNKER, where his AMAZON ARTWORK is all ove the walls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lost City of Z White 7/31/15 94, The troops--about twenty--sit around a table, packed into cavernous room. Seated at the table is MADAME KUMEL, a mystic. The soldiers see Fawcett; HENRY COSTIN is here! * Costin shouts out: *

dialogues.speaker: HENRY COSTIN
dialogues.text: Won’t you join us, sir! We're having a mysticism--a medium of * fine spiritualist skills! Costin approaches:

dialogues.speaker: HENRY COSTIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (sotto) She'll bless us for the fight with * Fritz. With a bit of the occult-- * part of the world that isn’t right in front of our face, if you know what I mean.

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: Yes... I surely do. (to the Madame) We'll be in battle soon, madame. Any spiritual aid we can get--I think we’d all very much like your blessing.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY COSTIN
dialogues.text: Madame, how ‘bout you read the Major? The whole group CHEERS the idea. Madame Kumel motions for Fawcett to sit down. Fawcett sits and the men CHEER WILDL Manley ENTERS the BUNKER. *

dialogues.speaker: MADAME KUMEL
dialogues.text: (the men told her) You are the explorer?

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: I am. As are these fine men, who have transferred here, to be with me. Points to Costin and Manley, who cheer. She reaches over, takes an Indian NECKLACE that Fawcett has wrapped around hand like a bracelet. She slips it off. She looks up at the WALL, SEES THE JUNGLE ARTWORK. She begins to HYPNOTIZE THE ROOM. She holds the object and wi her other hand holds Fawcett’s:  Lost City of Z White 7/31/15 95.

dialogues.speaker: MADAME KUMEL
dialogues.text: Feel my hand... Listen to my voice. Only my voice... Only my voice. Empty your mind, the only thing is my voice... Fawcett stares at the mesmerizing Madame.

dialogues.speaker: MADAME KUMEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You have loved ones at home?

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: I do... My wife, and children...

dialogues.speaker: MADAME KUMEL
dialogues.text: But you are not home. Can you take me where you are...? (beat) Can you take me to where you dream to be?

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: It is far away...

dialogues.speaker: MADAME KUMEL
dialogues.text: Is it the forest? (beat) You wish to be in the forest?

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: I wish to find a lost city...

dialogues.speaker: MADAME KUMEL
dialogues.text: Can you see yourself there, now...? Try to picture it, in your mind.

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: Yes. I can. I can see it, in the jungle. My family is with me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We SEE Kumel and Fawcett, at the table--which is now situ in the middle of the jungle. NINA and THE CHILDREN are SEATED AROUND HIM--JACK’S BACK is to US. We still HEAR ONLY the SOUND FROM THE BUNKER and the soun of the WAR. KUMEL CONTINUES:

dialogues.speaker: MADAME KUMEL
dialogues.text: Your place is beyond the jungle city. A timeless place.  90 91 92 Lost City of Z White 7/31/15 96.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are in what looks like a more extensive Machu Picchu. There are GOLD STATUES, ENORMOUS, everywhere. Still, we H ONLY THE SOUND FROM THAT BUNKER. And yes, now Kumel and Fawcett are around the table in the middle of the ruins:

dialogues.speaker: MADAME KUMEL
dialogues.text: I see a valley... A valley anda great city, full of jewels. (beat) A wealth of real jewels and gold. But also jewels of the spirit... THE EXPLOSIONS GET LOUDER. AND LOUDER. THEN, a BEAUTIFUL

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONISTS BUT SEEMINGLY COVERING THE GROUND LIKE SNOW.
dialogues.text: Kumel continues:

dialogues.speaker: MADAME KUMEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Your soul is not quiet. You must find this new world. It is your destiny. You seek escape from our world, escape from its cruelties and customs...

dialogues.speaker: FAWCETT IN THE JUNGLE 91
dialogues.text: Seated, by himself. The CAMERA DOLLIES IN, SLOWLY:

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Our world has set itself afire...and we must look elsewhere to quench the blaze...

dialogues.speaker: ALL OF A SUDDEN, A DEAFENING EXPLOSION SHATTERS THE MOMEN
dialogues.text: and we are BACK IN:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which has been hit by a shell. The men all scatter, in panicked chaos... Fawcett covers his head from the fallin debris... A close call... The rain of gold flakes was actually falling dirt... Fawcett exits the bunker, into:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: +e HF

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
