dialogues.text: 93 94 Lost City of Z White 7/31/15 97.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The troops, looking weary and beyond battle-scarred, star CAMERA as we DOLLY PAST THEM. They cower from the shells. We're in Fawcett’s POV. FAWCETT PATROLS THE TRENCH. Fawcett then looks over to SEE a LOW PRIVATE, shaking lik leaf. The Private has vomited all over his uniform. Fawce then charges through the trench, YELLING HIS SPEECH:

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: When I was younger, I ventured all for King and Country, for place, and rank. I believed that to be the makings of a man. But my travels have taught me that such ambitions are mere phantoms. Phantoms that exclude humanity from the Garden of Eden. My dear friends, what DOES matter--the only thing that matters--is the esteem we show our fellow man. In our hearts we fight for our loved ones; as they are not here today, we fight for each other. (beat) Good luck and may God be with you.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY COSTIN
dialogues.text: And fuck the bloody Boche! Everyone laughs, including Fawcett. Then the men separate, begin to line the trenches. Cleani their rifles, making sure the bayonets are screwed on tightly. Readying the charge. Many men start throwing up; others kiss small bibles; others look at family photos wh they kiss and place in their breastpockets. Others are merely still, awaiting almost certain death. Fawcett take small drawing of AMAZONIA JUNGLE, holds it to his head. Almost like he’s praying to it. Then pockets it. We SEE: ROWS OF HORSES, getting GAS MASKS put on their he INDIAN TROOPS are getting ready to mount them, and are adorned in the most elaborate and absurd manner...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fawcett takes several steps near the top of the trench. Places a whistle in his mouth. Looks at his men, who are donning GAS MASKS. Raises his arm and BLOWS THE WHISTLE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 95 96 Lost City of Z White 7/31/15 98. Upon blowing the whistle, an army of men charge out of th trench with a collective BATTLE CRY. Among them, the Low Private. ALMOST INSTANTLY, so many of the men are RIDDLED WITH MACHINE GUN FIRE. Others are SET AFIRE with FLAMETHROWERS. EXPLOSIONS ALL AROUND. Mines. Shells. Brutally loud. THEN: THE TWO INDIAN CAVALRY REGIMENTS GALLOP out of the TRENCHES; the HORSES HAVE GAS MASKS OF THEIR OWN. Absurd. They charge toward the German position, but are SET ON FI by FLAMETHROWERS and HIT BY THE HAIL OF BULLETS. Huge numbers of new troops leap from the trenches, many to be with a similar fate. Wounded infantrymen crawl into shell holes. Fawcett himse emerges from the trench. Sees ARTHUR MANLEY, shrieking. Then MANLEY gets his FACE BLOWN OFF. Costin charges right along with Fawcett.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fawcett whips off the gas mask and starts to yell. Scream to his soldiers, often inaudible from the devastating sou of war, we can nonetheless tell what he’s saying either b reading his lips or by the occasional word peaking throug

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: Come on! Come on! Come on!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A GONG sound. CHEMICAL WEAPONS are coming. HENRY COSTIN

dialogues.speaker: HENRY COSTIN
dialogues.text: Incoming! Gas! Fawcett stands in the middle of the battlefield, seemingl man on his own. And in his own world. Men shrink and char forward around him; men die around him; men courageously stand their ground. BULLETS and FLAMES seem mysteriously to avoid him; he see impervious... SMOKE seems to envelop Fawcett in his craze dazed state. He holds up his rifle with its bayonet into air. He has a THOUSAND-YARD STARE NOW...  97 Lost City of Z White 7/31/15 99. AND THEN WE HEAR IT: A GONG SOUND. A nearby explosion. Fawcett falls to his knees. His mouth opens in lockjaw an his eyes roll back into his head. He falls... WE PAN OFF HIM TO REVEAL: bits of letters and photos that men carry into battle flutter over the corpses like snow. CAMERA MOVES through the battlefield, littered with the papers and blood and parts of bodies. The camera settles, finally, on a piece of BARBED WIRE. Attached to it: the DRAWING BY FAWCETT of AMAZONIA. Stain with blood, moving gently in the wind...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fawcett, in the hospital. In bed, somewhere in England. H awakens, dazed, shocked--by the EYE PATCHES which cover h eyes. NINA FAWCETT is here, with the three children behin her. She approaches the bedside as he moves. She TEARS UP Fighting the tears, she smiles, puts on a brave face:

dialogues.speaker: NINA FAWCETT
dialogues.text: Darling, it is I. We’re here--the children are here. The children walk to Fawcett’s side, all muttering “HELLO Jack is now a young adult; Brian, a young teen; and young daughter JOAN a toddler.

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: Let me kiss you all. Nina lifts the toddler Joan, and Fawcett kisses her. Fawc strokes the top of Brian’s head tenderly. PERCY FAWCETT (CONT’D) Joan, and Brian...where’s Jack?

dialogues.speaker: JACK FAWCETT
dialogues.text: Here, father. Jack steps forward, CRYING. Then to Nina:

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: What’s...happened to me...?

dialogues.speaker: NINA FAWCETT
dialogues.text: They say you’ve been exposed to chlorine gas. Your eyes were affected, but with any luck, your sight shall return. And--you’re here, darling. You’re with us, and that is what matters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: + eH  Lost City of Z White 7/31/15 100. Fawcett lifts his head a bit, straining for sensation. A DOCTOR is here, too.

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: What about Costin? The rest of the men?

dialogues.speaker: NINA FAWCETT
dialogues.text: Mr. Costin was unhurt. As for your division, they suffered many losses-— -but far fewer than others. It is the most death in the history of any battle. (beat) But darling, because of your bravery, the Germans have retreated, all along the front. We've made His Majesty aware of what you’ve done. And they're going to award you with the distinguished service order. They've also agreed to raise your rank to Lieutenant Colonel. Jack cannot help himself, but, appalled, he blurts out:

dialogues.speaker: JACK FAWCETT
dialogues.text: Lieutenant Colonel? After all he’s done?!?

dialogues.speaker: NINA FAWCETT
dialogues.text: (not now) Jack... The young man, still in tears, takes several steps backwa and sits on a bench.

dialogues.speaker: NINA FAWCETT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We'll bring you home as soon as we're able, darling.

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: (beat) What about--what about my travels? To Amazonia? Nina cannot answer this. She looks to the Doctor:

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: I...I’m afraid you may never be able to return to your jungle. Percy Fawcett shuts his eyes in quiet disappointment and turns away. The Doctor attempts to cheer him: +e %

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 98 99 Lost City of Z Pink Revision Set 8/24/15 101.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: However, you can take comfort in the fact that here we’ll be able to offer you the very best care in all the civilized world. Fawcett turns back to the Doctor when he hears this:

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: “Civilized”? That word is an obscenity. I’ve been years in that jungle, with so-called savages. And none would ever bring such horror and destruction on his fellow creatures. Percy turns away. Everyone takes the hint--Nina pats everyone out. But staying is JACK. Jack sits down ina chair against the wall. NINA TURNS to OBSERVE: PERCY FAWCETT (CONT’D) (sotto voce) Jack...? Jack approaches his father’s bedside. Without being able make eye contact, Fawcett somehow finds his son’s FACE. H TOUCHES it, FEELING ITS CONTOURS--then touching the young man’s tear...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SUPERIMPOSE: “STOKE CANON, ENGLAND. 1923”.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The camera PANS PAST many objects from the Fawcett past. HEAR an AMERICAN MAN’S VOICE, a reporter whom we never se AMERICAN MAN’S VOICE (0.C.) Our readers have been asking where you've been since the war. America has quite a fascination with you. ANGLE ON PERCY AND NINA FAWCETT, seated on a couch. Nina holds young Joan; Percy pets the family dog.  Lost City of Z Pink Revision Set 8/24/15 102.

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: I'm grateful for their interest. You may tell your readers I’ve recovered from my wounds and have adapted to home life. The family’s lived in many places--Jamaica, also in America, briefly. We've only just returned to England.

dialogues.speaker: NINA FAWCETT
dialogues.text: It’s been quite wonderful to have him with us for this time.

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: Yes--my family’s needs are above all now. AMERICAN MAN’S VOICE (0.C.) But your pursuits in South America led to tremendous interest in exploration in the United States. There have been many new voyages planned. Percy Fawcett perks up. NEW voyages?

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: Have there...? AMERICAN MAN’S VOICE (0.C Well, Dr. Hamilton Rice is headed to Brazil soon...with radio, and airplanes. Fawcett gets up, walks over to a large MAP of South Ameri He stares at it. ANGLE ON FAWCETT still looking at that m AMERICAN MAN'S VOICE (0.C. (CONT’D) He’s taking a large and very well- armed party.

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: We can only hope that--with all of his arms, Dr. Rice doesn’t destroy what he wishes to discover... (turns back to the reporter) Tell me, how did you find us here? AMERICAN MAN’S VOICE (0.C.) (surprised) Your son, Colonel. He wrote us a letter--didn’t he tell you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lost City of Z Pink Revision Set 8/24/15 102A. ANGLE ON FAWCETT as we GO TO:  100 101 Lost City of Z Pink Revision Set 8/24/15 103. EXT. LARGE FIELD —- CLOUDY DAY 100 We HEAR distant GUN SHOTS. The wind howls. Then we SEE, emerging from over a hill, Jack Fawcett, holding a RIFLE. RABBIT runs through the grass. Jack raises his rifle, FIR again. He hits the RABBIT. Percy and Nina Fawcett emerge, having seen the shot.

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: You've become quite expert with that rifle!

dialogues.speaker: JACK FAWCETT
dialogues.text: Thank you, father. After he recovers, he WATCHES HIS SON RUN to GET THE RABB JACK PROUDLY HOLDS UP THE CARCASS. Father stares at _son, something on his mind. Then, re the rabbit:

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: No no, I’1l retrieve it... As Percy goes to get the animal, Nina has a private momen with Jack:

dialogues.speaker: NINA FAWCETT
dialogues.text: I know you feel remorse about the harsh words you said to him. But that was years ago. He loves you. Go talk with him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The RABBIT hangs from a tree. Fawcett and Jack are settle here, atop a hill, overlooking the field. Fawcett stands, lighting a small cigar; Jack sits, cleaning his gun. Fawcett PETS THE HANGING CARCASS of the rabbit, then lowe it from the string and begins to prep it for eating.

dialogues.speaker: JACK FAWCETT
dialogues.text: Father...?

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: Mmm?

dialogues.speaker: JACK FAWCETT
dialogues.text: I realize how fortunate I am not to have lost you in the war. When we came back to England, I saw how few of my friends still had their fathers.  Beat. Lost City of Z Pink Revision Set 8/24/15 104.

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: (nods; then) It’s been a difficult few years for many. (beat) You've been writing to the American newspapers about us, I’m told.

dialogues.speaker: JACK FAWCETT
dialogues.text: I have. I’ve been reading of your exploits. They are quite extraordinary.

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: I’ve something for you. Fawcett pulls something out of his bag: AN INDIAN NECKLAC He gives it to Jack:

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: It was from a Guarani Indian. It’s yours now.

dialogues.speaker: JACK FAWCETT
dialogues.text: Thank you... It’s remarkable... (beat) The Americans are going to Amazonia now. I’m sickened by the thought that they might steal your thunder.

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: (a broad smile) I’ve little enough thunder to steal, my boy. I never did find 2.

dialogues.speaker: JACK FAWCETT
dialogues.text: You must not say that! I’ve read of your achievements--you are a great man! You still believe in Z, do you not? That we have always underestimated the Indian?

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: (beaming at his son’s enthusiasm) Of course...

dialogues.speaker: JACK FAWCETT
dialogues.text: Then why don’t we go back? You and I, together--to find the lost city once and for all?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lost City of Z Pink Revision Set 8/24/15 105.

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: (taken aback; a flood of emotion) I--I don’t know if I able, Jack.

dialogues.speaker: JACK FAWCETT
dialogues.text: I know you are. You easily outmatch my strengths. Fawcett STANDS, looks out at the VISTA as Jack continues:

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: I am touched by your faith in me. But--the war took its toll.

dialogues.speaker: JACK FAWCETT
dialogues.text: Father, the Americans will venture there with their guns. And then we must pray they do not destroy the Indian. We must beat them to the spot. (beat; he smiles) I want to go with you so much, I want nothing more. (beat) We could find Z. You and I can do it.

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: On this, Jack, we must consult a higher authority. (beat) Your mother, I mean. Jack lets out a laugh. Then:

dialogues.speaker: JACK FAWCETT
dialogues.text: Father, there is something else I can barely speak of. I wish...to apologize for the disgraceful things I said to you before you went away. Fawcett turns back, looks at Jack.

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: You were only doing your best to protect all of us. (beat) The hero in you was speaking. Fawcett approaches Jack. Offers him a hand:  Lost City of Z Pink Revision Set 8/24/15 106. PERCY FAWCETT (CONT’D) Come. We’ll conquer your mother’s reserve together...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fawcett, silhouetted in the unlit office. He is SILENT. Only the daylight illuminates the room. Jack faces NINA.

dialogues.speaker: JACK FAWCETT
dialogues.text: Please, Mother. I know it’s dangerous. But you’ve said yourself with...with all that’s happened--it’s not possible to choose a safe passage through life. So many men near my own age did not return from the war--and who is to say it will not happen again?

dialogues.speaker: NINA FAWCETT
dialogues.text: By all rights I should be furious. You’ve used my very own words against me. (fighting with herself) Yet I do not refute them now-- indeed, try as I will, I cannot.

dialogues.speaker: JACK FAWCETT
dialogues.text: (beat; gets emotional) Please...

dialogues.speaker: NINA FAWCETT
dialogues.text: (looks at Percy; then) There’s little doubt I would worry night and day about my two boys in the jungle. But...your father and I have never let fear determine our future-- Jack gets up and excitedly kisses his mother, who looks l than overjoyed.

dialogues.speaker: JACK FAWCETT
dialogues.text: Thank you so much, Mum. Thank you!

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: We’re not there yet, Jack. These journeys require a great deal of money and training.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lost City of Z Pink Revision Set 8/24/15 106A.

dialogues.speaker: JACK FAWCETT
dialogues.text: Of course, father... But I shall begin preparing immediately, nonetheless! You and I, and perhaps Mr. Costin, too. He’l1l come, I know it! Jack leaves the room. Fawcett turns to maps on his desk, starts collecting them.  103 Lost City of Z Yellow Revision Set 8/6/15 107.

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: I admit I’m surprised by your speedy acceptance.

dialogues.speaker: NINA FAWCETT
dialogues.text: Did I have another choice? It would be wrong to betray his nature now. (beat) If you shall go, the both of you, then you must find Z, once and for all.

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: Yes...we shall see it through... I‘'1ll go see Mr. Costin. (beat; looks at her) You're concerned about Jack? She does not answer. PERCY FAWCETT (CONT’D) He'll perform splendidly. I've learned from the past that character is more important than experience. The CAMERA PANS to the WINDOW, to SEE JACK RUNNING. OUTSI IS YOUNG JOAN, playing. Fawcett watches them both, then: PERCY FAWCETT (CONT’D) The boy has what it takes, I’m sure.

dialogues.speaker: NINA FAWCETT
dialogues.text: (brightening; a laugh) He should--he is my son, after all!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is the elegant club in London. A place for gentlemen. Not a place for Percy. Men in black tie, men drinking brandy. HENRY COSTIN is here, looking older, simultaneous more settled yet more shattered. Percy sits across from him. Both are in high-backed leath chairs, and a small table sits between the two. Costin op a large BRIEFCASE sitting next to his chair. Withdraws something... Costin places NOTEBOOKS on the table and slides them to Fawcett. With a smile:  Lost City of Z Yellow Revision Set 8/6/15 107A.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY COSTIN
dialogues.text: In fine condition, Chief. All my notes. I hope they are of help to you. Percy takes them as one would handle a delicate child.  Lost City of Z White 7/31/15 108.

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: Can I truly not persuade you to come with us? Costin averts Percy’s gaze. Percy leans forward. Whispering: PERCY FAWCETT (CONT’D) We were so close before--and think of what it would mean, for all human history.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY COSTIN
dialogues.text: I’m honored you still consider me worthy. But...things have changed. I've a wife and children now.

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: I would remind you that when we went on our travels, my own children were younger than yours are now. (leans back, subtly introspective) I did have my fair share of concern about their welfare, it’s true. (leans forward again, louder) Yet my son today--if you were to see his character, his vim and vigor, for yourself, it would tear down your resistance in an instant. A WAITER comes over:

dialogues.speaker: WAITER
dialogues.text: Would you like some more brandy, sir?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY COSTIN
dialogues.text: No, thank you, Nigel. The Waiter leaves. HENRY COSTIN (CONT’D) Chief--I do not doubt Jack’s excellence. But I’m afraid you and I part ways in this regard. For me, the search for Z--I can no longer bear the cost, you see.

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: (surprised) You doubt its existence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: + eH + eH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: eee

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 104 Lost City of Z White 7/31/15 109.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY COSTIN
dialogues.text: No. Not for a moment. But I do doubt that it can ever provide all the answers you require from it.

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: You feel I romanticize the significance of 2. Costin begins to protest. Fawcett stops him: PERCY FAWCETT (CONT’D) The charge does not dismay me. But let the world stand in judgement once I knock the scales from their eyes. Do not doubt me, my friend. Costin breaks out into a huge smile.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY COSTIN
dialogues.text: God bless you, Colonel--you'’ve not lost your fire. (beat) Forgive me, I cannot say yes. (beat) I wish you godspeed and the greatest success.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SUPERIMPOSE THE LEGEND: “LONDON. DECEMBER 3, 1924”. Percy Fawcett talks to a syndicate of newspapers. A press conference. REPORTERS and PHOTOGRAPHERS pack the room. Ja Fawcett and Nina are here, too, by Fawcett’s side. So are host of cigar-smoking financiers...

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: This will be no pampered expedition. Top-heavy missions get nowhere; they linger on the fringe of civilization and bask in publicity. We will not. Our journey will last three years. A tribesman will take our messages to bring them to you as often as we can, for you to publish.

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER
dialogues.text: Who is financing this latest journey of yours? + eH +e % +e HH OH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 105 Lost City of Z White 7/31/15

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: The money is generously being supplied by a consortium of American newspapers and Mr. John D. Rockefeller, Jr.

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER
dialogues.text: Are you aware the Royal Geographical Society has just offered to help with the financing?

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: I am glad to see our nation is not to be left behind.

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER
dialogues.text: What about America’s own explorers? They're in South America now, with great technology--

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: I’m not concerned with them--we have our own plans. I would like to introduce to you now my son, Mr. Jack Fawcett. ANGLE ON JACK, who is beaming. PERCY FAWCETT (CONT’D) He will be my companion on this historic expedition. (Fawcett looks at his son) He is strong as a horse and keen as mustard. FLASH! go the cameras. Then we HEAR:

dialogues.speaker: SIR GEORGE GOLDIE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Well, we could not very well be shamed by the Americans, now could we.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fawcett and Jack, inside a large conference room. 110. 105

dialogues.speaker: A GROUP OF
dialogues.text: PEOPLE is standing there, getting ready to SAY GOODBYE to PERCY FAWCETT: KELTIE, WILLIAM BARCLAY, others. SIR JOHN SCOTT KELTIE (CONT’D) I’m proud to say, we did finally meet them halfway... (sobers; sheepish) Percy, this organization has not... (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lost City of Z White 7/31/15 111. SIR JOHN SCOTT KELTIE (CONT’D) always recognized you as perhaps we should have in the past.

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: Our differences were always honorable, Sir John.

dialogues.speaker: SIR JOHN SCOTT KELTIE
dialogues.text: (nods; then) Sir George, rest in peace, always bore you great affection. But I admit my error in not accepting your beliefs long ago. Fawcett takes out his COMPASS. Moves close to Keltie.

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: When I find Z, I shall send it to you. Consider it a sign. Keltie looks at it.

dialogues.speaker: SIR JOHN SCOTT KELTIE
dialogues.text: Godspeed, Percy. A NEARBY CHURCH BELL RINGS in the now-quiet room. SIR JOHN SCOTT KELTIE (CONT’D) We do have something here for you, at the Society. (beat) Mr. Barclay? William Barclay OPENS A WOODEN CASE. Inside: SIR JOHN SCOTT KELTIE (CONT’D) It’s our highest honor. The Founders’ Gold Medal. ANGLE ON JACK. His eyes widen; he is truly impressed.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM BARCLAY
dialogues.text: You are truly deserving, Colonel. Truly.

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: (virtually moved to tears) I’m grateful... (beat) My son and I will rejoice in telling you the whole story in three years time. eee

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 106 Lost City of Z Pink Revision Set 8/24/15 112. Fawcett grabs both arms, squeezes. Jack has a smile from to ear. Champagne is served, and the men toast--in SILENC

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A TRUCK is idling. Percy and Jack Fawcett are loading it with supplies. Alongside them are the rest of the family: Nina, Brian, Joan.

dialogues.speaker: NINA FAWCETT
dialogues.text: All the arrangements are completed-- we're off to Portugal on the 7th and then we meet in Brazil.

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: Good. Now remember: the code with the coordinates--a copy is in my desk and another is in safekeeping, with Mr. Costin. (beat) No one will trump us now... Awkward silence as Nina begins to turn inward. PERCY FAWCETT (CONT’D) Well, I suppose that’s all. I/’11 send you the dispatches, for the newspapers.

dialogues.speaker: NINA FAWCETT
dialogues.text: Jack-- She gestures to his suit coat handkerchief, which is fall out. Fawcett, meanwhile, moves close to her, out of earsh of anyone else:

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: Cheeky, if I should not come back-- do not look for me. If one of us lives, we all shall live.

dialogues.speaker: NINA FAWCETT
dialogues.text: (as though his death is an insane thought) I’ve complete faith in you. You'd better get going, you'll miss your boat. Fawcett moves to Brian, who is quiet.  107 Lost City of Z White 7/31/15 113.

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: You're a man now, responsible for your mother and sister’s care. It’s a fine calling, no less and perhaps more virtuous than ours. No response. Percy Fawcett takes out a sealed LETTER.

dialogues.speaker: NINA FAWCETT
dialogues.text: Brian? Say goodbye to your father. And tell him how much you'll miss him.

dialogues.speaker: BRIAN FAWCETT
dialogues.text: Goodbye, father. I shall indeed miss you. As I always have.

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: I’ve written something for you. Brian takes it. Fawcett kisses Joan: PERCY FAWCETT (CONT’D) Dear Joan. Take care of your mother.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN FAWCETT
dialogues.text: Goodbye, father.

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: On to Z, then. And a new history. Fawcett then leans over, kisses Nina briefly, and unsentimentally boards the truck. Jack hugs Nina, who the turns and gets in the truck as well. Brian watches as his father and brother WAVE. He looks do at the ENVELOPE FROM HIS FATHER. FAWCETT AND JACK WAVE as the TRUCK DRIVES OFF... INT. FAWCETT STOKE CANON HOME - BRIAN’S BEDROOM - NIGHT 1 Brian opens the envelope: a poem. Starts reading.

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Never forget us, brave little man Mother and father trust in you. Be brave as a lion, yet kind returning

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: 108 109 Lost City of Z White 7/31/15 114.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The ship at sea, on its way to South America. We STILL HE

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Ready to fight and averse to wrong... Never forget you’re a gentleman And never a fear you’ll do.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: STILL PHOTOS of the AQUITANIA, a huge SHIP. WIDE SHOTS. 1 Then CLOSE SHOTS of JACK AND PERCY on the DECK, WAVING. BLACK AND WHITE STILLS.

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Life is short and the world is wide.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: SERIES OF SHOTS of Fawcett’s house and old Ireland ARMY 1

dialogues.speaker: BARRACKS
dialogues.text: THE ARMY BARRACKS in Ireland - empty, save the usual post move detritus. THE BEDROOM - empty. Dust now. ARMY BACKYARD - empty. Windswept, covered with leaves. THE FRO LAWN - empty. A child’s TOY, covered in dirt.

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: We’re just a ripple on life’s great pond. We END with: INT. NEW MADEIRA HOME - NINA’S BEDROOM - NIGHT 111 A new ROOM, in Madeira. Nina is asleep with a newspaper o her lap. It reads, “EXPLORERS ENTER JUNGLES TO SEEK LOST RACE”. Then we HEAR a LOUD TRAIN WHISTLE:

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Enjoy your life to the best you can, All will help enrich the span,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the train into the jungle, they pass parades for the Carnival. They pass beautiful fields, vistas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: + eH  114 Lost City of Z White 7/31/15 115. Crowds wave to them. Jack stands, looking out the window. Fawcett remains seated, eyes a map.

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: But never forget you’re a gentleman.

dialogues.speaker: JACK FAWCETT
dialogues.text: Forty million, father! The newspaper said forty million are following our journey! Look, even here! Fawcett stands, looks out the train. Sotto:

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: It is rather marvelous... Fawcett turns to look at the people waving at the train.

dialogues.speaker: A SLIGHTLY WISTFUL YET ALSO ENTHUSIASTIC PERCY
dialogues.text: FAWCETT; he waves back to them.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: SERIES OF SHOTS as we STILL HEAR the train: The CAMERA 11 DOLLIES PAST a sleeping Nina in the MADEIRA HOME. Next: t CAMERA DOLLIES PAST a sleeping Brian. Last: PAST a sleepi Joan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Loses his STETSON HAT. It blows away. THE HAT TWISTS AND SPINS AND FLOATS IN THE WIND, eventually leaving our sigh

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: (to Jack) We are getting closer. The CAMERA SPINS PAST the COUNTRYSIDE--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE SHOT: Fawcett. He consults a map. ZOOM OUT: DWARFED BY NATURE, THE AWESOME DEPTHS OF THE JUNGLE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: +e * HF

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lost City of Z Green Revision Set 09/30/2015 116. Jack is right behind him. The Peons (Indian messengers) a near but bringing up the rear and looking exhausted. SUPERIMPOSE: “PANTANAL REGION, BRAZIL. APRIL 30, 1925”. Percy turns to Jack.

dialogues.speaker: JACK FAWCETT
dialogues.text: My compass appears to have stopped working.

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: It’s nothing to fret over--I’ve two others. How are you faring?

dialogues.speaker: JACK FAWCETT
dialogues.text: I’ve rarely felt better.

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: Good. We’ll be on the river soon-- and then if we’re lucky, to see an opera... EXT. FAZIENDA JACOBINA —- CLEARING 116 Out of the jungle comes our group. They are close to the that served as an opera house... But it seems abandoned. Fawcett leads the group toward it front doors, which are swinging open... The old opera hut house is still in the jungle, but this it is COVERED WITH VINES, overgrown with weeds and spider

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fawcett cannot believe what he sees. The jungle is swallowing up the structure, with spiderwebs and detritus The men stand in the center, stunned. The camera PULLS BA TO REVEAL A RUIN being OVERRUN BY MONKEYS. PERCY FAWCETT

dialogues.speaker: LEFT STANDING IN THE MIDDLE OF THE DILAPIDATED STRUCTURE
dialogues.text: the PRIMATES SWIRL AROUND HIS LEGS. SWARMS OF VAMPIRE BATS SHRIEK ABOVE THEIR HEADS...  120 Lost City of Z Green Revision Set 09/30/2015 117.

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: A pity you could not see it intact... (brightens ) No matter. We’ll hit the river as scheduled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Percy and Jack and the Peons have made a canoe. They SLID IT OFF, into the RIVER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The men in their canoe. They move through the river. AND THEN: Bodies. Floating. WHITE MEN, looking EMACIATED. FACE DOWN. NUMBERING AROUND TEN OR SO... FAWCETT seems to accept it. JACK is terrified... THE CANO MOVES PAST THE CORPSES... THE PEONS are in the canoe behi them. ANOTHER SWARM OF BATS SWOOPS PAST THEM...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack hacks away at a tree with his machete, collecting firewood. A PEON, looking feverish, approaches Percy as h sits by the fire. He has been writing in a notebook. In Portuguese:

dialogues.speaker: PEON, (SUBTITLE)
dialogues.text: Mr. Fawcett, our work is done. We warn you, past this point is only danger. Fawcett stands.

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT, (SUBTITLE)
dialogues.text: You have acquitted yourself wonderfully. We are grateful for your efforts. (reaching down, into a stack of his papers and envelopes ) (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 121 122 Lost City of Z White 7/31/15 118.

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT, (SUBTITLE)
dialogues.text: Please--if you could deliver this final dispatch... The Peon nods, takes the ENVELOPE.

dialogues.speaker: MOMENTS LATER
dialogues.text: WIDE SHOT of group. The Peons say GOODBYE, shaking hands, and disappear into the jungle. Our men are alone now. Fawcett and Jack walk off into the jungle in the opposite direction...

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Dearest Cheeky, this is the last letter you shall receive until we reach Z.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The men get off the canoe and ENTER THE DEEP JUNGLE. They look thinner now, more worn.

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: As always, we have encountered some setbacks. But Jack is acquitting himself marvelously. Today we reached a tribe of Bakairi Indians, who told us of a cave entirely unknown to anyone outside their clan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Bakairi village. The men enter the place and speak with the Indians. CLOSE SHOT of PERCY FAWCETT as HE TAKES PICTURES WITH HIS CAMERA, which is mounted on a TRIPOD. Our CAMERA DOLLIES INTO an EXTREME CLOSE SHOT on the camera’s LENS... PERCY FAWCETT (V.O.; CONT’D) They tell of an enormous rock there, covered with painted pictures of men and horses. Its location is perhaps the gateway to Zeee SERIES OF BLACK AND WHITE PHOTOS of the INDIANS:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: + eH +e HF

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 123 124 125 Lost City of Z Green Revision Set 09/30/2015 119. In the photos, Jack and Fawcett all pose with the “savage Standing in different positions, some holding arrows, som merely seated. Other photos show the Indians in the middl of ritual, crouched, dancing, upright, with spears, in a circle, etc. CLOSE SHOT on PHOTOGRAPHS FLOATING THROUGH THE STREAM,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Near Dead Horse Camp. Fawcett EYES the camp... He and Jac approach it...

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: ..-I expect we will be in touch with the old civilization within a month, and to be at the main objective in August.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nina is at her desk, reading the letter:

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Thereafter, our fate is in the lap of the gods. (beat) You need have no fear of any failure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fawcett and Jack walk down a muddy path. Fawcett takes no while walking. Then:

dialogues.speaker: JACK FAWCETT
dialogues.text: Father-- Fawcett looks up from his journal to SEE: RED-MASKED SUYA TENS OF THEM. FAWCETT motions for JACK to stop, then TAKE ONE SINGLE STEP FORWARD. A SINGLE ARROW WHIZZES BY HIS HEAD. SUYA INDIANS are ABOU 200 YARDS away. STARING.  126 127 Lost City of Z Green Revision Set 09/30/2015 120.

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: Stay calm. I know precisely the approach. Confident, he tries his signature approach with the SUYA. begins to walk toward them, waving his handkerchief:

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT, (SUBTITLED)
dialogues.text: Friend! Friend!

dialogues.speaker: AND THEN
dialogues.text: CLOSER. THEY DON’T STOP.

dialogues.speaker: ALL OF A SUDDEN
dialogues.text: A SPINNING CLUB OF WOOD, about three feet in length, come seemingly from nowhere. WHOOP WHOOP WHOOP--A PUNISHING BLOW TO THE HAND. A WAR CLUB, then another. Realizing his tried-and-true plan will not work, Fawcett takes his RIFLE OFF HIS SHOULDER AND FIRES: He shoots one of the Suyas in the stomach. The Indian ble

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: profusely and falls down, dying...

dialogues.speaker: FAWCETT SEES THIS AND HIS FACE WRINKLES IN ANGUISH
dialogues.text: PERCY FAWCETT (CONT’D) Oh Lord... (recovering) Into the brush! Fawcett and Jack bolt into the dense jungle, and so do th Indians, in pursuit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fawcett and Jack run for their lives. A chase on foot has begun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 128 129 Lost City of Z Green Revision Set 09/30/2015 121. The camera is HAND-HELD now, tossing back and forth, our characters’ POV. DISORIENTED... A sound: WHIRRING. What is that? CLUBS. CLUBS OF WOOD. WAR_CLUBS. The Suyas are HURLING THEM through the trees, presumably.

dialogues.speaker: FOREST.
dialogues.text: SPINNING AND MOVING AT INCREDIBLE SPEED. And they are com CLOSE TO US, millimeters from FAWCETT’S HEAD. Fawcett duc them as he bolts through the trees. WHOOSH! Jack, away from Fawcett, is hit in the chest. It knocks him over, but he gets up and continues to run.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who is moving through the forest with great speed, determ to survive. In his POV, the denseness becomes DIZZYING, obscuring, difficult. We HEAR the WHIRRING and his HURRIE BREATHING. Fawcett gets up. He is on the move again as ARROWS DART P HIM, PERILOUSLY CLOSE...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fawcett reaches the riverbank. Jack is here on his knees, with his back to us. Is he dead? He’s oddly still. Fawcet approaches his son. THEN HIS SON TURNS, TERRIFIED. IN SHO and SHAKING.

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: They'll keep after us--we’ve got to keep moving. Fawcett grabs his son, shakes his head. PERCY FAWCETT (CONT’D) Do you hear me?!?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fawcett and Jack are running in tall grass. Then they sto Surrounded by Indians. They have more PAINT on them, more MUD, than the other group of Indians that were chasing th earlier.  130 Lost City of Z Goldenrod Revision Set 10/18/15 122. Fawcett and Jack turn around. Indians close in behind the too. DOOMED? ONE INDIAN STEPS FORWARD. HE TAKES HIS SPEAR and HURLS IT RIGHT TOWARD FAWCETT. Fawcett thinks this is the END. Instead, it goes past him, and THWOK! HITS ANOTHER INDIAN

dialogues.speaker: RIGHT BEHIND HIM. KILLS THE MAN. THE OTHER INDIAN, A SUYA
dialogues.text: was POISED WITH BOW AND ARROW, ready to kill Fawcett.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THIS INDIAN HAS SAVED FAWCETT’S LIFE. WARRING TRIBES. The Indians fire at each other, as Fawcett and Jack duck down into the grass...

dialogues.speaker: THE SUYAS RETREAT... THE NEW GROUP OF INDIANS SURROUND
dialogues.text: FAWCETT AND JACK. Fawcett looks up, raises his hands...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fawcett and Jack sit in the middle of the Indian tribal village. A RAIN BEGINS TO FALL. LIGHTNING and THUNDER, though in the distance. A low rumble, then nothing but rain... Fawcett whispers to his son:

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: I’ve encountered this before. We’re in no real danger. Jack nods. A KAYAPO INDIAN plays with a FLASHLIGHT that Fawcett has given him. Fawcett and Jack are seated with t Indians surrounding them. The Indian appears thrilled wit the flashlight. Two other Kayapos are in a debate:

dialogues.speaker: KAYAPO INDIAN
dialogues.text: The Christian is not one of us.

dialogues.speaker: KAYAPO INDIAN
dialogues.text: He is not one of them, either. (beat) He is a shadow man, never at rest...we must send him back to the shadows... The Kayapo BRING IN THREE CORPSES, THE SUYA INDIANS WHOM KILLED. The bodies are tied up on TREE BRANCHES. And PUT OVER THE FIRE. Jack’s EYES POP as he sees this.

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: They eat the ash of the bodies. They believe it saves their enemy's souls.  131 Lost City of Z Goldenrod Revision Set 10/18/15 123.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Kayapo lead Jack and Percy up a PATH of ROCK. They li them down in a circle of ROCKS. In Portuguese:

dialogues.speaker: KAYAPO INDIAN
dialogues.text: Sleep... Percy nods. The Kayapo SEEMS entirely friendly. And they place ONE TORCH in between TWO LARGE ROCKS.

dialogues.speaker: JACK FAWCETT
dialogues.text: Are...are we going to die? Fawcett looks to his son for a moment, cupping his son’s in his hand. Then his eyes unexpectedly turn to the heave and he begins:

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: “Hast thou commanded the morning since thy days, and caused the dayspring to know his place? Who hath put wisdom in the inward parts? Or who hath given understanding to the heart?” (his head sinks; not making eye contact with his son, but to his son) Most of life is a mystery. We know so little of the world. But we’ve made a journey other men cannot even imagine. And it has given understanding to our hearts. We do not need to know the future. Jack sits up. Then he STANDS. PERCY FAWCETT (CONT’D) Jack, sit down. They need to know that we trust them.

dialogues.speaker: JACK FAWCETT
dialogues.text: Father... (beat) Is--is this not 2?

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: No... Zed is over those mountains. Let us hope we’ll be on our way soon.

dialogues.speaker: JACK FAWCETT
dialogues.text: But--I believe we may have already reached part of Z. +e %

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lost City of Z Goldenrod Revision Set 10/18/15

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: Temper your enthusiasm, my boy. We've not yet reached our coordinates.

dialogues.speaker: JACK FAWCETT
dialogues.text: Do you not see the causeways you’ve described? They’re perfectly straight and stretch as far as the eye can see. And a bridge as well! The ancient Indians must have forged something truly astonishing. Imagine the plans, the skill, all of them working together, to achieve it! Percy stands and takes a few steps to see the causeway. JACK FAWCETT (CONT’D) And you just told me how they were saving the souls of their enemies. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lost City of Z Goldenrod Revision Set 10/18/15 124. JACK FAWCETT (CONT’D) That is the sort of civilization your opponents always denied could exist here. (beat) We are IN Z, father! It’s all around us! Percy takes a step forward. Looks around. A STUNNING REVELATION--in the look of SHOCK--SEEMS TO COME OVER HIS FACE. JACK FAWCETT (CONT’D) One day the whole world will see it, without doubt. It’s everything you've always wanted! Percy EYES his son, then breaks down. He begins to cry.

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: My boy, to be here with you, on this journey...is everything. Fawcett tenderly grabs Jack’s neck. Percy then withdraws LETTER from his pocket, hands it to Jack Fawcett.  132 133 Lost City of Z Green Revision Set 09/30/2015 125. PERCY FAWCETT (CONT’D) Your mother gave this letter to me some time ago. It’s given me great strength over the years. You should have it now. Jack takes it. CLOSE SHOT ON THE LETTER, as it is being opened. Then, MUSIC UP: A KAYAPO DANCE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Tribe does a ritual dance around Fawcett and Jack. Th then approach the men, who sit, kneeling with their heads down. A Kayapo then begins to paint Fawcett and his son, GIVING THEM SOME KIND OF MILKY DRINK. The Indians paint t men’s chests too, around their necks and sterna.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A close shot on Percy Fawcett. He stares at his son, who appears to be at peace. FAWCETT turns away. Seems to drif off. We PUSH EVER CLOSER ON HIM. He looks over, at the GROUND. He SEES: the LETTER from NINA. Then: all sound fr the jungle disappears. We:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A CLOSE SHOT of NINA, MUCH YOUNGER THAN WHEN WE LAST LEFT HER. SHE IS HOLDING A BABY. WIDEN to REVEAL: A dining table, covered with food. Crowded with presumabl family and friends. A CHEER goes out. Nina and Fawcett stand at the head of the table, having just arrived with their newborn: JACK. Lord Bernard is here, too, as are th other faces from our story’s opening at the church. (The scene is UNNATURALLY QUIET, almost like a HALLUCINATION. it’s an event that it’s happened, a FLASHBACK.)

dialogues.speaker: RANDOM WOMAN
dialogues.text: So wonderful, little Jack! (to Nina) And you--you look so robust, and healthy!

dialogues.speaker: NINA FAWCETT
dialogues.text: Thank you... Yes. I do feel better. Fawcett pulls out a chair for Nina and the baby. Then:

dialogues.speaker: LORD BERNARD
dialogues.text: A toast--shall we?  LAUGHTER. LAUGHTER. Lost City of Z White 7/31/15 126.

dialogues.speaker: NINA FAWCETT
dialogues.text: Yes, Lord Bernard. But--I--I would * like, if I could, to read something first. *

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: (as a joke) * Now I’m in for it! *

dialogues.speaker: NINA FAWCETT
dialogues.text: I wrote it for you. In the event I * did not survive the birth.

dialogues.speaker: LORD BERNARD
dialogues.text: Oh, but you did, my dear, thank * heavens! She begins, reading off a small piece of stationery as Fawcett eyes her:

dialogues.speaker: NINA FAWCETT
dialogues.text: “My Percy, I know your first instinct will be to grieve, but I adjure you rather to consider our son and the love you must show him--" (looking at young Jack) See--? I knew it would be a boy, and born on the birthday of the Buddha, no less! * (only some laughter; back to * letter) “--Always teach him to dream. For * as the Buddha teaches, to seek the unknown, to look for what is beautiful, is its own reward. And I beg you to remember those words so easy to forget, written by our beloved Browning--allow me one last time to repeat them: “a man’s reach should exceed his grasp, or what's a heaven for?” My dearest love forever, Cheeky.” The women at the table let out a collective “AWWWW” as Fawcett smiles, kisses his wife’s hand. He then looks ove to the baby, reaching out to touch its hand. We MATCH CUT  134 135 Lost City of Z White 7/31/15 127.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're back where we were. Or are we? It’s oddly silent, save for Fawcett’s breathing. Percy touches his son’s han

dialogues.speaker: PERCY FAWCETT
dialogues.text: We're here, Jack... You’re right... Z is all around us... CLOSE UP ON PERCY FAWCETT as the Indians dance, lifting a moving him somewhat sloppily. It is not tender, but it is not violent, either. Fawcett turns: musicians and dancers circle what looks li plaza. In the distance: mound-shaped houses in endless ro They hold him aloft... He reaches up. SEES something. Tries to touch it. We SEE what PERCY FAWCETT SEES: SILHOUETTED: A GATEWAY, a LARGE ARCH, in the distance, through the trees. Across th river. The Indians carry FAWCETT AND NOW JACK too. The KAYAPO be a march... They CARRY PERCY AND JACK up toward the GATEWA which is HIGH ABOVE the community...

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: A TITLE CARD: “FOUR YEARS LATER”

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seated behind his desk: SIR JOHN SCOTT KELTIE. Keltie is near eighty now. ENTERING: WILLIAM BARCLAY. Keltie does n look up from his notes. After an awkward beat:

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM BARCLAY
dialogues.text: Sir John?

dialogues.speaker: SIR JOHN SCOTT KELTIE
dialogues.text: Yes...?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM BARCLAY
dialogues.text: She's outside again. Keltie seems both sympathetic and peeved. After a beat:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lost City of Z White 7/31/15 128.

dialogues.speaker: SIR JOHN SCOTT KELTIE
dialogues.text: Bring her in. Barclay spins around, opens the door. Entering the room: NINA FAWCETT. Keltie gets up, smiles. Puts on his best behavior in her presence.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM BARCLAY
dialogues.text: Miss Nina.

dialogues.speaker: SIR JOHN SCOTT KELTIE
dialogues.text: Nina my dear, how are you?

dialogues.speaker: NINA FAWCETT
dialogues.text: Sir John... Mr. Barclay.

dialogues.speaker: SIR JOHN SCOTT KELTIE
dialogues.text: How may we be of help to you today? Nina speaks, but in a way that is almost interior, trancelike. Her eyes have a kind of thousand-yard stare, she seems to connect, then turn inward, from moment to moment:

dialogues.speaker: NINA FAWCETT
dialogues.text: A man...came to see me yesterday.

dialogues.speaker: SIR JOHN SCOTT KELTIE
dialogues.text: A man?

dialogues.speaker: NINA FAWCETT
dialogues.text: He was from Brazil. He’s seen Percy, and Jack, living with the Indians. He says they claim to have reached Z. Keltie tries to hide his skepticism, but cannot. Reaches to Nina. Tenderly:

dialogues.speaker: SIR JOHN SCOTT KELTIE
dialogues.text: My dear, it’s been years. Almost a hundred men now have been sent to look for your husband and son. I‘m...I’m afraid they are no more. And I would advise... He cannot continue. Tears well up in her eyes--and, amazingly, he gets emotional as well.

dialogues.speaker: NINA FAWCETT
dialogues.text: Sir John, I confess that the brutal wear and tear is great, and I suffer with heart and soul. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lost City of Z Green Revision Set 09/30/2015 129.

dialogues.speaker: NINA FAWCETT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It has taken all my strength of will to push horrors out of my thoughts... Then Nina seems to reconnect: NINA FAWCETT (CONT’D) But I beg you not to lose confidence. I cannot doubt--after so many years of sacrifice--it has become my own life’s work. It cannot have all been in vain...

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM BARCLAY
dialogues.text: Miss Nina, we do plan more search parties. We do. No response. Keltie looks pained. He sits back down, behi his desk.

dialogues.speaker: NINA FAWCETT
dialogues.text: The Brazilian gave me this, to give to you. He said Percy told him you would understand. Nina hands him THE COMPASS. Keltie takes the COMPASS. Tri to reveal not a hint of wide-eyed shock. BUT HE IS SHOCKE NINA FAWCETT (CONT’D) I have trained myself to be impartial to evidence, but surely this is a sign.

dialogues.speaker: SIR JOHN SCOTT KELTIE
dialogues.text: (in a state of shock) I--I will have it examined...

dialogues.speaker: NINA FAWCETT
dialogues.text: Thank you, Sir John. It is all I can ask. Nina withdraws again. DEVASTATED BY HIS WORDS. A beat, an then she nods, turns, leaves. Keltie looks up after she h left. Takes the compass in his hand, is WHITE AS A SHEET!

dialogues.speaker: SIR JOHN SCOTT KELTIE
dialogues.text: (to himself) Good God...

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM BARCLAY
dialogues.text: What is it, Sir John? Anything? At all?  Lost City of Z White 7/31/15 130. Sir John looks up at Barclay. We: *

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nina enters the hall. The camera PANS with her. We WATCH her solitary figure walk off, back to us... And as she ma the turn in the hallway, she enters: THE JUNGLE. THE HALL becomes DARK JUNGLE! SHE DISAPPEARS INTO THE DARKENSS. An

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: + eH then we HEAR:

dialogues.speaker: A NARRATOR
dialogues.text: Many rescue groups were sent to find Percy and Jack Fawcett, but none was successful. Nina Fawcett kept hope that they would return up until her death in 1954.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An aerial SHOT of the Amazon river, snaking through GREEN FOREST... A NARRATOR (CONT’D) Though many recognized Fawcett’s attitude toward the peoples of Amazonia to be ahead of its time, his belief in a lost city was ridiculed for almost a hundred years. But early in the 21st century, scientists were astonished to discover key evidence of ancient roads, bridges, and complex agricultural systems spread throughout the jungle: an advanced civilization. (beat) The modern age had come to see, in * this way too, that Percy Fawcett * was correct. CUT TO BLACK. The End
